4 in the first cycle and 2 in the second cycle
2 in the first cycle and 2 in the second cycle
4 in the first cycle and 4 in the second cycle

questions.solution:
• The First Cycle of FAS Complex 2 C from Acetyl CoA condenses with 2 Carbon atoms of Malonyl CoA, by liberating 1 CO, So 4 Carbon atoms added.

questions.text: True statement is/are:? Total body water constitutes about 60% of body weight ? Most intracellular water is the musculoskeletal system ? questions.text: A 19-year-old man presented with a mild form of phenylketonuria. The diagnosis was first made when he was examined for the tremor at 18 years of age. The main aim of first-line therapy in this patient should be:

choices.text: Limiting the substrate for the deficient enzyme
Giving the missing amino acid by diet

questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria also called PKU, is a rare inherited disorder that causes an amino acid called phenylalanine to build up in the body. PKU is caused by a defect in the gene that helps create the enzyme needed to break down phenylalanine.
The primary goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain.
Treatment of Classical PKU
? A low-phenylalanine diet
? Administration of large neutral amino acids (LNAAs) is another approach to diet therapy.
? Sapropterin dihydrochloride (Kuvan), a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients with residual PAH activity, is approved by the FDA to reduce phenylalanine levels in PKU.
Preliminary trials with recombinant phenylalanine ammonia-lyase have been encouraging and demonstrated reduced blood levels of phenylalanine during treatment

questions.text: A 66-year-old man sought medical care at the hospital due to severe chest pain lasting for 24 hours. The patient was aware of being hypertensive and was a smoker. If the cause is thrombus occlusion of coronary vessels, then all of the following arteries are common sites of occlusion by a thrombus EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
? Marginal arteries are rarely the sites of coronary vaso-occlusive disease.
? There are two main marginal arteries: 1. Acute marginal (branch of right coronary) and 2. Obtuse marginal (branch of circumflex, left coronary artery).
? The anterior interventricular artery is a branch of the left coronary artery and is the most common (50%) artery to be occluded by the thrombus in the coronary circulation.
? The second most common artery to be occluded is the main trunk of the right coronary artery (30%).
? The posterior interventricular artery is a branch of the right coronary artery and the incidence of thrombosis is statistically less.
? The third most commonly thrombosed artery is the circumflex artery - a branch of the left coronary artery.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy reported to the hospital with the features shown in the image. The family history revealed a hereditary pattern of the disease with similar features being exhibited in milder degree in the patient's younger brother. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Mucopolysaccharidosis II (Hunter Disease)

Biochemical defect

  • X-linked disorder caused by the deficiency of iduronate-2-sulfatase (IDS)
  • Point mutations of the IDS gene mapped to Xq28 have been detected in about 80% of patients with MPS II
  • Hunter disease manifests almost exclusively in males; it has been observed in a few females and this is explained by the skewed inactivation of the X chromosome carrying the normal gene.

Clinical features

  • MPS II has features similar to those of Hurler disease except for the lack of corneal clouding and the somewhat slower progression of somatic and central nervous system (CNS) deterioration
  • Coarse facial features, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, joint stiffness, and mental retardation manifest between 2 and 4 years of age
  • Grouped skin papules are present in some patients.

questions.solution:
In the case of EDH - The source of bleeding is typically from a torn meningeal artery, usually the middle meningeal artery (75%)

Foramen Contents
Foramen rotundum Maxillary division of trigeminal nerve
Foramen spinosum Middle meningeal artery, nervus spinosus
Foramen lacerum No structure passes through this foramen, but the upper part is traversed by the internal carotid artery (and sympathetic plexus around), deep petrosal nerves, and greater petrosal nerves joining to form vidian nerve of pterygoid canal
Foramen cecum Emissary vein from the nasal mucosa to the superior sagittal sinus

questions.text: (A) True od (B) False about the branches of the abdominal aorta:1. Superior Mesenteric Artery is located at L1 vertebral level and supplies viscera that derive embryologically from the forgut2. The celiac Trunk is located at the T12 vertebral level and supplies the intra-abdominal portion of esophagus, stomach, upper part of duodenum.3. Inferior Mesenteric Artery is located at L2 vertebral level and supplies viscera that derive embryologically from the midgut4. Common Iliac Arteries are the terminal branches of the abdominal aorta
questions.solution:
Major Branches of Abdominal Aorta
? The celiac Trunk is located at the T12 vertebral level and supplies viscera that derive embryologically from the foregut (i.e., intra-abdominal portion of esophagus, stomach, upper part of duodenum, liver, gallbladder, and pancreas). The celiac trunk further branches into the following.
a. Left gastric artery
b. Splenic artery
c. Common hepatic artery
? Superior Mesenteric Artery is located at L1 vertebral level and supplies viscera that derive embryologically from the midgut (i.e., the lower part of duodenum, jejunum, ileum, cecum, appendix, ascending colon, and proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon)
? Renal Arteries supply the kidneys.
? Gonadal arteries supply the testes or ovary.
? Inferior Mesenteric Artery is located at L3 vertebral level and supplies viscera that derive embryologically from the hindgut (i.e., distal one-third of transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and upper portion of the rectum).
? Common Iliac Arteries are the terminal branches of the abdominal aorta.
? Collateral Circulation: The abdominal vasculature has a fairly robust collateral circulation. Any blockage between the superior mesenteric artery at L1 vertebral level and inferior mesenteric artery at L3 vertebral level will cause blood to be diverted along two routes of collateral circulation. The first route uses the middle colic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) which anastomoses with the left colic artery (a branch of the inferior mesenteric artery). The second route uses the marginal artery.

questions.text: Biotin, also called vitamin B7, is one of the B vitamins. It is involved in a wide range of metabolic processes, both in humans and in other organisms, primarily related to the utilization of fats, carbohydrates, and amino acids. It is a cofactor of:
questions.solution:
Coenzyme role of Biotin
Play a role in gene expression, fatty acid synthesis, gluconeogenesis and serve as a CO2 carrier for Carboxylases enzymes and gene regulation by histone biotinylation
Coenzyme for ATP dependent Carboxylation reaction (Carbon Dioxide Fixation)

  • Pyruvate Carboxylase (Pyruvate to Oxaloacetate)
  • Propionyl CoA Carboxylase (Propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA)
  • Acetyl CoA Carboxylase (Acetyl CoA to Malonyl CoA)
  • Methyl Crotonyl CoA Carboxylase


Biotin independent Carboxylation reaction

  • Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase –I & II
  • Addition of CO 2 to C 6 in Purine ring (AIR Carboxylase)
  • Malic Enzyme (Pyruvate to Malate)

questions.text: All are true about the salient features of Watson–Crick Model of DNA except?

choices.text: Grooves often act as sites of DNA–Protein interaction needed for regulation of gene expression
Guanine pair with Cytosine by 4 Hydrogen bonds
The DNA Protein interaction is via hydrophobic interaction and ionic bond

questions.solution:
Salient Features of Watson–Crick Model of DNA

1. Right-handed double-stranded DNA helix
2. Base Pairing Rule

  • Adenine always pairs with Thymine
  • Guanine pairs with Cytosine.

3. Two strands are antiparallel. The polarity of DNA is such that

  • One strand runs in 5’ to 3’ direction
  • The other strand runs in 3’ to 5’ direction.

4. Hydrogen Bonding

  • Adenine pairs with Thymine by 2 Hydrogen bonds. (A = T)
  • Guanine pair with Cytosine by 3 Hydrogen bonds (G = C)

5. Grooves of the DNA: They are two types:

  1. Major groove
  2. Minor groove
  • Grooves often act as sites of DNA–Protein interaction needed for regulation of gene expression.
  • The DNA Protein interaction is via hydrophobic interaction and ionic bond.

questions.text: Non-shivering thermogenesis is classically defined as a cold-induced increase in heat production not associated with shivering activity. This Non-shivering thermogenesis in adults is due to?
questions.solution: Nonshivering thermogenesis was originally defined as a cold-induced increase in heat production not associated with the muscle activity of shivering. Recent research shows it to be a metabolic process located primarily in brown adipose tissue and controlled by the activity of the sympathetic nervous supply of this tissue. Another stimulus to sympathetic nervous activity, the ingestion of inferior and lateral in the territory of the food, promotes diet-induced thermogenesis middle cerebral artery, whereas the lower in brown adipose tissue.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented to the clinic with ecchymosis and bloody urine, abdominal distention, fever, loss of appetite, and extreme weight loss. His past 6-month history revealed that he easily got fatigued. He had also been suffering from recurrent epitaxy since past 1 year. Bone marrow aspiration revealed the finding shown in the image. The probable diagnosis of this patient is
questions.solution:
The given image shows Guacher’s cells are seen as large cells with a thin outer border, one or two eccentric nuclei with few cytoplasmic content (arrows).

Gaucher’s Disease

  • Most common Lysosomal Storage Disorder
  • Glucocerebrosidase defect
  • Lysosomes filled with Glucocerebroside
  • No cherry red spot in the macula
  • No mental deterioration (Type I)
  • Hematological features: Pancytopenia, bleeding manifestation
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Bone Pain and Pathological Fractures of long bones
  • X-ray Femur Erlenmeyer Flask Deformity
  • Bone Marrow Biopsy Gaucher cell with Wrinkled paper appearance/crumbled tissue paper appearance.

questions.text: Somites are precursor populations of cells that give rise to important structures associated with the vertebrate body plan and will eventually differentiate into dermis, skeletal muscle, cartilage, tendons, and vertebrae. At the end of 5th week of gestation, how many numbers of somites can be seen?
questions.solution:
The first pair of somites arises in the occipital region of the embryo at approximately the 20th day of development.
• From here, new somites appear in craniocaudal sequence at a rate of approximately three pairs per day until, at the end of the fifth
week, 42 to 44 pairs are present.
• The first occipital and the last five to seven coccygeal somites later disappear (now the total is 37), these remaining somites form the
axial skeleton.
• Because somites appear with a specified periodicity, the age of an embryo can be accurately determined during this early time
period by counting somites.

questions.text: Cell motility helps ensure that your cells get to where they're supposed to be. That's especially important in developing tissues. The protein that helps in this process of cell motility is:
questions.solution:
? Tubulins are the structural subunits of microtubules, which regulate cell motility.
Microtubules
? Long, hollow structures with 5-nm walls
? Made up of two globular protein subunits: α- and b-tubulin (stacked rings, with each ring usually containing 13 subunits). A third subunit, g-tubulin, is associated with the production of microtubules by the centrosomes.
? The tubules interact with GTP to facilitate their formation.
? Microtubules are polar with assembly predominating at the “+” end and disassembly predominating at the “–” end.
? Functions:
- Intracellular transport
- Cilia and flagella
- Centriole-mitotic spindle
? Motilin is a 22-amino acid polypeptide hormone in humans, which regulates intestinal motility.
? Laminin is an extracellular matrix protein, which regulates cell development and growth. Others matrix proteins with similar functions are collagens, bronectin, tenascin, and various proteoglycans.
? Tactilin: no such term in the medical dictionary.

questions.text: Because gaseous exchange in the respiratory system occurs only in the terminal portions of the airways, the gas that occupies the rest of the respiratory system is not available for gas exchange with pulmonary capillary blood. With each quiet inspired breath, the fraction of alveolar air getting replaced would be?
questions.solution:
? At the end of quiet expiration, the volume of air remaining in the lung is the functional residual capacity (FRC). The volume of FRC = 2300 mL. This is the existing alveolar air.
? With the next quiet breath, about 500 mL (TV) is inspired. Of this, 150 mL stays in the dead space and 350 mL air will reach alveoli. This 350 mL air (with oxygen) will replace 350 mL alveolar air (containing CO2) to be mixed with dead space air and exhaled out.
? Out of 2300 mL of existing alveolar air, 350 mL air is getting replaced. 350/2300 = (approx.) 1/7th fraction.

Hyperammonemia Type II (OTC Deficiency)

? Urea cycle disorder with Orotic Aciduria
? Marked elevations of plasma concentrations of glutamine and alanine with low levels of citrulline and arginine
? Orotate may precipitate in urine as pink-colored gravel or stones.

questions.text: A case of a 45-year-old female presented with features of malignant hyperthermia. On the extensive study of the patient there was a mutation of the gene coding for the ryanodine receptors. Which of the following statements best explains the increased heat production in malignant hyperthermia?

choices.text: Increased muscle metabolism by excess of calcium

questions.solution: Malignant hyperthermia has been traced to a mutation in RyR, the Ca 2+ release channel in the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The mutation results in an inefficient feedback mechanism to shut down Ca 2+ release after stimulation of the RyR, and thus, increased contractility and heat generation.”

questions.text: Structures passing through the superior thoracic aperture are all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The superior thoracic aperture measures 5 cm anteroposteriorly and 10 cm transversely.
? It is kidney-shaped, bounded by manubrium anteriorly, the first rib laterally, and the first thoracic vertebrae posteriorly
? It slopes down and forwards so that the apex of the lung extends upwards into the neck behind the anterior end of the first rib.
? Structures that pass between the thorax and the upper limb, therefore, pass over the first rib and the apices of the lungs and the apical pleurae.
In the given question:
? Left (and not right) recurrent laryngeal nerve passes through the superior thoracic aperture.
? Right recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks around the right subclavian artery in the neck region and ascends up in the tracheoesophageal groove to supply the larynx.
? Left common carotid artery is given by the arch of the aorta in the superior mediastinum (thorax). This artery has to pass the thoracic aperture to enter the neck region, where it bifurcates into external and internal carotid arteries
? The sympathetic trunk begins at the foramen magnum, passes through the thoracic aperture to reach the thorax, then goes through an opening in the diaphragm to reach the abdomen, and terminates in front of the coccyx.
? Thoracic duct begins at the upper end of the cisterna chyli in the abdomen, it passes posterior to the diaphragm to reach the
thorax. It then passes through the thoracic aperture and enters the neck region, where it terminates in the neck veins.

questions.text: A 34 year old man came to your OPD for general check up and on lab work up an increased level of serum potassium was noted. Which of the following can lead to a state of Hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:
Exercise causes hyperkalemia because the Na+-K+ pump cannot keep pace with the K+ efflux from muscle during the depolarization-repolarization process of the sarcolemmal membrane during muscle contraction.
Causes of the shift of K+ out of cells i.e. Hyperkalemia:
? Insulin deficiency
? Beta adrenergic antagonist
? Acidosis
? Hyperosmolarity
? Inhibitors of Sodium potassium ATPase pump
? Exercise
? Cell lysis
Causes of shift of K+ into cells i.e. Hypokalemia:
? Insulin
? Beta adrenergic agonist
? Alkalosis
? Hypoosmolarity

questions.text: You are an intern in pediatric department watching your senior doctor doing an lumbar puncture in an infant. All are true regarding the anatomy of spinal cord in an infant except:

choices.text: The ligamentum flavum and dura mater are not as thick in infants and children as they are in adults
In premature and term neonates, the spinal cord usually terminates between the first and third lumbar (L1-3) vertebrae
The conus typically reaches the adult level (L1) by 4 years of age
In children between the ages of 1 and 7 years, the conus medullaris lies between the twelfth thoracic and third lumbar vertebrae

questions.solution:
Lumbar Puncture in Neonate and Infant
? In premature and term neonates, the spinal cord usually terminates between the first and third lumbar (L1-3) vertebrae.
? With growth of the spine, the conus typically reaches the adult level (L1) by 2 years of age.
? In children between the ages of 1 and 7 years, the conus medullaris lies between the twelfth thoracic and third lumbar vertebrae.
? The supracristal plane intersects the vertebral column slightly higher (L3–4).
? A needle with trocar is inserted into the back between the spines of the third and fourth lumbar (L3/L4) vertebrae or L4/L5 interspinous levels below the level of the conus medullaris.
? The space between l3 and l4 is approximately level with the iliac crests and it is usual to insert the needle and trocar into the intervertebral space immediately above or below the iliac crests.
? The ligamentum flavum and dura mater are not as thick in infants and children as they are in adults. therefore, it is difficult to assess when the needle passes through them into the subarachnoid space because the characteristic “pop” or “give” may be subtle or nonexistent in the pediatric lumbar puncture.

questions.text: Your an intern and your senior doctor shows you an image of oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve with a rightward shift as shown below. All are probable cause for the shift of the curve except:
questions.solution:
Oxygen-Hb Dissociation Curve (OHDC)
? This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the% saturation of Hb with O2 . It is normally sigmoid-shaped due to co-operative binding property of hemoglobin.
? P50 : It is the partial pressure of oxygen at which Hb is 50% saturated. In arterial blood it is 26 mm Hg and in venous blood it is 29 mm Hg.
Shift to the right means:
If the OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O 2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) and P50 has increased.
Factors causing rightshift:
? ↓ pH
? ↑ CO 2
? ↑ in temperature
? ↑ in 2,3-DPG

questions.text: Assertion: Clara cells present in bronchioles secrete surfactant protein that line the bronchioles and play a role in the defense system of the airwaysReason: Clara cells are stem cell responsible for regeneration of cilliated epithelium & helps in xenobiotics metabolism

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true statement and reason is correct explanation for assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true statement but reason is not correct explanation for assertion
Assertion is independently true statement, but reason is independently false statement
Assertion is independently false statement, but reason is independently true statement

questions.solution:
Clara cells (nonciliated cell) present in bronchioles.
? They secrete surfactant protein (SP-B) that line the bronchioles and play a role in the defense system of the airways.
? They are stem cell responsible for regeneration of cilliated epithelium (terminal bronchioles).
? Helps in xenobiotics metabolism (cytochrome p450 monooxygenase system).
? Clara cell secretory protein CC10 (CCSP) regulates inflammatory response and used as a Clara cell marker.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting presented with general fatigue and dyspnea on effort. Initial physical examination on admission to the general ward revealed bradycardia and a fourth heart sound immediately before the first heart sound. The fourth heart sound is caused by?

choices.text: Closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves

questions.solution: “A fourth sound can sometimes be heard immediately before the first sound whenatrial pressure is high or the ventricle is stiff in conditions such as ventricular hypertrophy. It is due to ventricular filling and is rarely heard in normal adults.”

questions.text: All are true about Operon concept, except:1. Lac operon concerned with lactose metabolism in prokaryotes2. Thiogalactoside Transacetylase is a carrier protein that helps permeation of lactose to cell3. Catabolite Activator Protein is a negative regulator of Lac Operon4. Lac I encodes lac operon repressor protein
questions.solution:
Operon Concept
• Lactose Operon by Francois Jacob and Jacques Monod in 1961
• Operon is the linear array of genes involved in a metabolic pathway, e.g. Lac operon concerned with lactose metabolism in prokaryotes.
Lac Operon Comprises of
i. Three structural genes coding for 3 proteins:
Lac z - Beta galactosidase
Lac y - Permease -a carrier protein that helps permeation of lactose to cell
Lac a - Thiogalactoside Transacetylase – function not known.
ii. Regulatory genes comprised of:
Lac promoter
Lac operator
Lac I encodes lac operon repressor protein.
Catabolite Activator Protein (CAP) in Lac Operon
? CAP is a Positive Regulator of Lac Operon
? If glucose concentration low - cAMP level is high
? CAP is complexed with cAMP
? CAP-cAMP Complex facilitates binding of RNA Polymerase to promoter
? Structural genes expressed.

questions.text: School health refers to a state of complete physical, mental, social and spiritual well- being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity among pupils, teachers and otherschool personnel. Which of the following committee gave the concept of school health first?
questions.solution:
School Health

  • Concept first laid by BHORE committee (1946)
  • Guidelines were laid down in detail by RENUKA ROY committee (1961)
  • Kartar Singh committee: Committee on multipurpose workers under health and family planning
  • Mukherjee committee : Basic health should be provided at block level

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the laboratory under the supervision of a microbiologist for learning. While preparing a small amount of a suspected TB patient specimen for purpose of microscopic examination, Which of the following will you use for digestion and decontamination of sputum in smear preparation?
questions.solution:
Sputum and specimens from non-sterile sites need prior treatment for digestion (to liquefy the thick pus cells and homogenization) and decontamination (to inhibit the normal flora) and concentration (to increase the yield).
? Petroff’s method (4% NaOH): Most commonly followed
? NALC (N-acetyl-cysteine) + 2% NaOH: This is superior to Petroff’s method for isolation. NALC liquefies the sputum and NaOH kills the normal flora. This method is better compatible with automated culture systems.
? If for only smear microscopy, then formalin or hypochlorite can also be used as mucolytic and for killing the bacilli. However, they are not useful for culture or animal pathogenicity.

questions.text: Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, aiming 100% coverage by 'catchup compaign' irrespective of previous immunization status, by 2020 against killer diseases. Which of the following vaccine is not included in Mission Indradhanush?
questions.solution:
MISSION INDRADHANUSH:

  • Launched by Ministry of Health & Family Welfare
  • Its aim is 100% coverage by 'catchup compaign' irrespective of previous immunization status, by 2020
  • Initially included vaccines against 7 vaccine preventable diseases (Now 12).They were:
  1. TB
  2. Polio
  3. Diphtheria
  4. Pertussis
  5. Tetanus
  6. Hepatitis-B
  7. Measles

Recently- Rotavirus, MR , IPV , JE are included in this.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement is true regarding Atazanavir:-
1. Effective against only HIV-1
2. Resistance is due to mutation in codon 50 isoleucine to valine substitution
3. Decrease cholesterol and triglyceride levels
4. Combination with ritonavir does not have any advantage
questions.solution:
• Atazanavir is effective against both against HIV 1 and HIV 2 but NNRTI are effective only against HIV 1.
  • They do not decrease cholesterol and triglyceride levels.
  • Combination with ritonavir have an advantage due to the phenomenon of Ritonavir boosting.
  • The resistance is due to mutation in codon 50 isoleucine to valine substitution.

questions.text: A couple has 4 children, all unvaccinated for Measles. A child got Measles on 5 August 2015. Two other children developed Measles by 15 August 2015. Secondary attack rate is:
questions.solution:
In the given question,

One primary case given rise to two secondary cases

Total susceptible = 3 (4 children minus primary case)

SAR = No. of secondary cases/ Total susceptibles X 100

So, SAR = 2/3 X 100= 66.6%

questions.text: The Classical markers for the disease which has the following biopsy finding shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Reed–Sternberg cells (also known as lacunar histiocytes for certain types). These are distinctive, giant cells found with light microscopy in biopsies from individuals with Hodgkin lymphoma
Hodgkin’s disease
? It is a group of lymphoid neoplasms arising in a single node and spreads from the nodes to spleen, then liver and finally bone marrow.
? Clinical importance of this predictable route of spread is highlighted by the importance of staging which determines prognosis as well guides the choice of therapy of HL.
? It is differentiated from non- Hodgkin’s lymphoma by the following features:

Hodgkin’s Lymphoma Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
More often localized to a single axial group of nodes ( cervical, mediastnal, para-aortic) More frequent involvement of multiple
Orderly spread by contiguity Non-contiguous spread
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring rarely involved Waldeyer ring and mesenteric nodes commonly involved
Extra nodal involvement Extranodal involvement common

? There is presence of neoplastic giant cell called Reed-Sternberg cell (derived from the germinal center B cell) which induces the accumulation of reactive lymphocytes, macrophages and granulocytes.
? In classical HL, CD15 and CD30 are the surface markers. In non-classical HL, CD20 and BCL/6 are the markers.

questions.text:
Match the giant cells with the conditions they are seen in:




1. Langerhans giant cell
2. Reedsternberg giant cell
3. Touton giant cells
4. Physiological giant cells


a) Hodgkin lymphoma
b) Xanthomas
c) Syncytiotrophoblasts
d) Tuberculosis
questions.solution:
It is a type of chronic inflammation characterized by the formation of granuloma. Granuloma is an aggregation of macrophages surrounded by a collar of mononuclear cells principally lymphocytes. Macrophages may get activated to form epithelioid cells (epithelium-like cells). Some of the
cells may fuse together to form a bigger cell called a giant cell. The giant cells can be primarily of the following types:
1. Langerhans giant cell: The nuclei in this giant cell are present in the periphery and in a horseshoe pattern. It is seen as tuberculosis.
2. Foreign body giant cell: The nuclei are arranged randomly or haphazardly here. It is seen in granuloma formed by foreign bodies like sutures, talc, etc.
3. Touton giant cells are seen in xanthomas, fat necrosis, xanthogranulomatous inflammation, and dermatofibroma. They are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells and contain a ring of nuclei surrounded by foamy cytoplasm.
4. Physiological giant cells are seen in osteoclasts, syncytiotrophoblasts, and megakaryocytes.

questions.text: A 8-year-old child presents with perivascular IgA deposition and neutrophilic collection. There is an erythematous rash on the lower limbs and non-blanching purpura as shown in the image. The likely diagnosis in the child is:
questions.solution:
? Henoch-Schonlein Purpura (HSP) is a syndrome seen in children (3-8 years of age) consisting of purpuric skin lesions characteristically involving the extensor surfaces of arms and legs as well as buttocks; abdominal manifestations including pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding; nonmigratory arthralgia; and renal abnormalities. It follows an upper respiratory infection.
? A history of atopy is present.
? The renal manifestations may include gross or microscopic hematuria, proteinuria, and nephrotic syndrome and are seen in 1/3 rd of the patients. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium.
Microscopically
? Kidney has the deposition of IgA, sometimes with IgG and C3, in the mesangial region.
? The skin lesions consist of subepidermal hemorrhages and necrotizing vasculitis with IgA deposition involving the small vessels of the dermis.
? Vasculitis also occurs in other organs, such as the gastrointestinal tract, but is rare in the kidney

questions.text: You are posted as a PHC medical officer, receiving an elderly patient with complaints of Polyuria, Polyphagia, Polyphagia. Blood investigations done revealed the diagnosis of Type 2 DM and you are deciding to start him on Metformin. Which of the below mentioned statements about biguanides like Metformin, started as first-line agent for Type 2 DM, is true?

choices.text: It cause little or no hypoglycemia
It stimulates pancreatic beta cells to release insulin
It is completely metabolized before excretion
Cannot reduce macrovascular events in type 2 DM

questions.solution:
BIGUANIDES

  • Metformin and phenformin are biguanides and are preferred agents for obese patients (as these are weight neutral and may even cause weight loss).
  • These can improve hypertri­glyceridemia in obese patients.

Biguanides do not stimulate the release of insulin, therefore have negligible risk of causing hypoglycemia.

Metformin is:

Totally excreted unchanged (without metabolism) by the kidney.

Useful for polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD)

First-line therapy for type 2 DM and cause maximum reduction in HbA1c levels.

  • Most antidiabetic drugs are made to reduce microvascular complications of diabetes like nephropathy, retinopathy etc.
  • Metformin is only oral agent to reduce macrovascular events in type 2 DM.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented to the ER with C/O 1-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and fatigue. Laboratory blood examination showed the following: Hb-2.6 g/dL, hematocrit 8.8%, MCV-85.1 fL, low reticulocyte count 6 × 109/L (0.7%), WBC-7.5 × 109/L, platelet count-274 × 109/L. If Pure red cell aplasia was diagnosed in this patient, she should be explicitly evaluated for which of the following?
questions.solution:
? In the rare pure red cell aplasia, the erythroid marrow elements are absent or nearly absent, while granulopoiesis and thrombopoiesis remain unaltered.
? This condition occurs in both primary and secondary forms, both of which are thought to be related to autoimmune destruction of erythroid precursors.
? There is a specific association between thymic tumors (thymoma) and autoimmune hematologic diseases, specifically including pure red cell aplasia.

questions.text: A patient comes in with complaint of intense joint pain in her left big toe for the past few months. On examination, you notice an erythematous swelling, which is tender on palpation and patient complains it has been on and off, for about 4 months time. You make a diagnosis of Chronic Gout. Which of following anti-gout drugs would you prescribe, given that it acts by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase?
questions.solution:
DRUGS USED IN CHRONIC GOUT

Group Mechanism Drugs
Uric acid synthesis inhibitors Xanthine oxidase inhibitors Allopurinol, Febuxostat
Uricosuric agents URAT-1 transporter inhibitors Probenecid, Sulfinpyrazone, Benzbromarone, Lesinurad
Recombinant uricase Cause oxidation of urate to allantoin Rasburicase, Pegloticase

questions.text: A elderly patient came in with symptoms suggestive of Acute CHF. Your senior consultant, advised you to give digoxin for the same. You being an over zealous intern, gave excess dosage of the drug and the patient suddenly developed ventricular arrhythmia. Which of the following monovalent cation would you give to reverse it?
questions.solution:
Potassium (K+) is a monovalent cation that can reverse a digitalis induced arrhythmia.

  • K+ and Digitalis binds on same receptor on Na+/K+ ATPase.
  • Hyperkalemia decreases Digitalis toxicity (digitalis induced arrhythmia) and Hypokalemia increases Digitalis toxicity.
  • Ca2+ facilitates the toxic actions of cardiac glycosides by accelerating the overloading of intracellular calcium stores that appears to be responsible for digitalis-induced abnormal automaticity.
  • Hypercalcemia therefore increases the risk of a digitalis induced arrhythmia.
  • The effects of Mg2+ are opposite to Ca2+. These interactions mandate careful evaluation of serum electrolytes in patients with digitalis-induced arrhythmias.
  • Lignocaine: DOC for digitalis induced arrhythmia
  • Digibind antibodies: Used in severe digitalis toxicity.

questions.text:
True statement regarding the p53 gene:
1.The ‘wild type’ of p53 gene and is associated with a reduced risk of the development of cancers2. The p53 gene inhibits the secretion of 53 KDa nuclear phosphoprotein, hence known as ‘molecular policeman’3. Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes the inactivation of p53 through its E6 protein4. p53 gene gives rise to neurofibromin which is a GTPase activating protein (GAP)
questions.solution:
p53 gene
? It is also known as ‘molecular policeman’ and ‘guardian of the genome’. The gene is present on chromosome 17p. The non-mutated p53 gene is also called the ‘wild type’ of p53 gene and is associated with a reduced risk of the development of cancers.
? Any inactivation of p53 prevents successful DNA repair in a cell leading to the development of a tumor.
? The p53 gene codes for 53 KDa nuclear phosphoprotein.
? In most cases, the inactivating mutations in both the alleles of p53 are acquired in somatic cells. However, sometimes individuals may inherit one mutant p53 allele and the second acquired ‘hit’ may inactivate the normal p53 allele. This latter condition is called Li-Fraumeni syndrome associated with the development of sarcoma, breast cancer, leukemia, and brain tumors.
? Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes the inactivation of p53 through its E6 protein and so, is responsible for the development of cancer of the anal and genital region.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child was brought to your clinic in a congenital hypercoagulability state. All of the following can lead to this state except:
questions.solution:
Anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome is an acquired cause of hypercoagulability

Primary (Genetics) Secondary (Acquired)
  • Mutations in factor V (Most common)
  • Antithrombin III deficiency
  • Protein C or S deficiency
  • Fibrinolysis defects
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Allelic variations in prothrombin levels
  • Mutations in the methyl tetra hydro folate (MTHF) gene
  • Prolonged bed rest or immobilization
  • Homocysteinemia
  • Tissue damage (Surgery, fracture, burns)
  • Cancer
  • MI, Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • DIC (Disseminated intravascular coagulation)
  • Heparin induced thrombocytopenia
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

questions.text: Hair scrapings from a patient with tinea capitis were taken and cultured on SDA. Figure shows the LCB mount. What is the likely identity of the causative dermatophyte?
questions.solution:
The likely identity of the causative dermatophyte is Microsporum gypseum.

M. gypseum is showing fusiform (spindle) shaped macroconidia.

Answers to other options:

  • M. audouinii - racquet shaped macroconidia.
  • E. floccosum - No microconidia, club shaped macroconidia (image below)
  • Macroconidia of Trichophyton: elongated with blunt ends (Pencil shaped)(image below)

questions.text: A 51-year-old female patient, who had systemic arterial hypertension and was under treatment with atenolol, was admitted to ER. The patient presented a 4–5 day history of severe headache, neck pain, chest discomfort, nausea, tachypnea and lightheadedness. Pheochromocytoma was diagnosed in this patient. To determine if the pheochromocytoma lesion is benign or malignant you can look for:

choices.text: Cannot be determined by microscopic examination

questions.solution:
Malignancy of pheochromocytomas cannot be determined by microscopic examination.

Pheochromocytomas, and their related counterparts in extra-adrenal sites called paragangliomas, are notorious because the only reliable indicator of metastatic potential is the presence of distant metastases. Very malignant-appearing tumors may not metastasize and benign-appearing tumors may produce metastases. These tumors should all be considered “potentially malignant.”

questions.text: A 47 year old male comes to your clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and excessive urination in the past 3 months. Patient sought consult since he had two episodes of bedwetting in the past week. On examination, you notice that the patient had dry skin and also complained of mild constipation. You order fasting, and random blood sugar which turns out to be normal. You fixate on a diagnosis of Diabetes insipidus, of nephrogenic origin. Which of the following would be the preferred medication for the same?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus
Central Nephrogenic
Desmopressin (DOC) Thiazides (DOC)
(As endogenous ADH is already present that is not able to work, so there is no point in giving ADH(desmopressin))

questions.text: A 90-year-old man was referred for evaluation of shortness of breath. He had a significant history of removing asbestos insulation from a US Navy ship 60?years earlier. He had quit smoking 30?years prior to the presentation. Physical examination was significant for inspiratory crackles. The most specific cancer-associated with this condition is:
questions.solution:
Diffuse interstitial fibrotic disease due to inhalation of asbestos particles in workers engaged in mining, pipes, brakes, insulation, and boilers.
• Initially, involvement of lower lobes of the lung pleural.
• In contrast to other dust, can also act as a tumor initiator and tumor promoter.
Interstitial fibrosis
? Pulmonary fibrosis with the presence of the asbestos body (iron-containing proteinaceous material coating asbestos fiber) and ferruginous body (iron protein complex coating other inorganic particles like talc, mica, fiber, glass, and other less common materials in the lung). True asbestos bodies are clear whereas the core of these particles is dark).
? The presence of asbestos bodies in or adjacent to the walls of fibrotic respiratory bronchioles is the hallmark of the disease.
Bronchogenic cancer
? Most common cancer associated with asbestos whose risk is increased with concomitant smoking.
Mesothelioma
? Localization of asbestos fibers in the lung close to the mesothelial layers increases the risk of the development of pleural and peritoneal mesothelioma. Concomitant smoking does not increase the risk of mesothelioma. It is the most specific cancer associated with asbestos inhalation.

questions.text: A patient with complains of burning sensation when urinating and lower abdominal pain presented to the outpatient department. She was on antibiotics for few days but there was no improvement. Urine sample was collected and sent for antibiotic sensitivity testing in the laboratory. What is the most Commonly used Disc diffusion method in antibiotic sensitivity testing?
questions.solution:
Disc Diffusion method is also known as Kirby Bauer disc diffusion method.

  • It is most commonly used method for antibiotic sensitivity testing.
  • It is done on MHA i.e. Mueller Hinton Agar or nutrient Agar.

Stokes method -

  • It is better method of disc diffusion because controls are used.
  • However, it is not used commonly because it is costly.

E test i.e. Epsilometer test is used to calculate MIC (minimum inhibitory Concenteration)

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of Schizophrenia presented to the emergency after ingesting a large glass of a pesticide diluted with water in response to auditory hallucinations. He was alert and in no apparent distress but had persistent hypotension and tachycardia that was unresponsive to fluid resuscitation. On HD 2 a reddish rash appeared on palms, soles, buttocks, and scrotum. It was documented as "Boiled lobster rash". This is seen in cases of poisoning with?
questions.solution:
Boric acid (Hydrogen borate/Orthoboric acid)

  • Weak acid, used as an antiseptic, insecticide (especially for cockroaches), flame retardant and as a neutron absorber.
  • GIT: mimics acute gastroentritis, nausea, vomiting (bluish-green), diarrhoea (bluish-green), haematemesis, and occasionally crampy abdominal pain
  • Skin: generalized erythemacreating a‘boiled lobster’appearance with massive areas of desquamation & exfoliation
  1. D/D: Toxic epidermal necrolysis, Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome
  2. Rash is particularly seen on the palms, soles and buttocks
  • CNS: Irritability, seizures, delirium and coma.
  • Renal: Oliguria, renal tubular damage and elevated serum creatinine.
  • CVS: Tachycardia, hypotension. Death results from circulatory collapse.
  • Medico-legal:
  1. Because of wide availability, accidental intake by children occurs frequently.
  2. It may be taken by mistake and suicidal purposes.

questions.text: Eight months old child had history of unusual crying and convulsions following previous vaccination after BCG, DPT & OPV (first dose) and Hepatitis B. Now parents have brought child for next doses of vaccination. Which vaccine is contraindicated in this situation?
questions.solution:
• Unusual crying following DPT is most likely to be Persistent Inconsolable Screaming.
  • Similarly, convulsions are most likely to be d/t DPT.
  • Hence, DPT should not be given subsequently.
  • It can be replaced by DT.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to explain about subclinical infection by his senior physician. Correct about Subclinical infection is all of the following except?

choices.text: It may be an early stage of an infection or a very mild infection.
These can be detected only by laboratory tests
Measles show a large number of subclinical cases.
It is an infection that has no symptoms or noticeable signs.

questions.solution:
SUBCLINICAL INFECTION

  • An infection that has no symptoms or noticeable signs.
  • May be an early stage of an infection or a very mild infection.
  • Seen in: Hepatitis A, diphtheria, Japanese encephalitis,Rubella, etc.
  • Not seen in Measles
  • Can be detected only by laboratory tests, e.g., recovery of the organism, antibody response , biochemical and skin sensitivity tests.

questions.text: Four populations had Correlation coefficients of + 0.6, each for weight and Height when plotted together. What would be the Net coefficient of correlation?
questions.solution:
• Generally, different correlation coefficients (r) cannot be averaged directly: as the value of ‘r’ is not a linear function of the magnitude of the relation between 2 variables
  • Average can be taken directly for coefficient of determination (r2)
  • In the given question (and graph), all correlation coefficient are same (+0.6), so their coefficient of determination would also be same (+ 0.62 =+ 0.36 for each distribution

Hence, they can be averaged to come out to be exactly “+0.6”

Combined correlation coefficient = √ (0.36 + 0.36 + 0.36 + 0.36)/4 = + 0.6

questions.text: A 11 yr old child , known case of epilepsy since the age of 9 months, and has been taking a medication regularly till date. He presents with fever, rash all over the body and noted lymphadenopathy. Which of the following medications do you think he might have consumed?
questions.solution:
Pseudolymphoma

  • It is a hypersensitive reaction to drug
  • Pseudolymphoma triad consists of
  1. Fever, generalized rash and lymphadenopathy
  • Anti epileptic drugs causing pseudolymphoma
  1. Phenytoin> Phenobarbitone> Primidone
  2. Carbamzepine

questions.text: A 63-year-old man becomes febrile and begins expectorating large amounts of mucopurulent sputum. Sputum cultures are positive for Gram-positive diplococci. Which of the following mediators of inflammation provides potent chemotactic factors for the directed migration of inflammatory cells into the alveolar air spaces of this patient?
questions.solution:
Chemotactic factors are substance that stimulalte cellular migration
The most potent chemotactic factors for leukocytes at the site of injury are:-
? Complement proteins (e.g., C5a)
? Bacterial and mitochondrial products, particularly low molecular weight N-formylated peptides
? Products of arachidonic acid metabolism (especially LTB4)

questions.text: A 37-year female presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of menorrhagia. On examination, the patient was pale-looking and her hemoglobin levels were 8 gm%. USG revealed left adnexal solid-cystic mass with mild heterogeneity. On HPE, mass revealed tumor cells being arranged in cords, solid sheets, trabecular pattern and at places microfollicular pattern with Call-Exner bodies. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Granulosa cell tumor:
? These are the most common type of ovarian tumor that is composed of cells that stain positively with inhibin.
? Histologically, the cells may form Call-Exner bodies, which are gland-like structures formed by the tumor cells aligning themselves around a central space that is filled with acidophilic material.
? The tumor cells may secrete estrogens and cause precocious sexual development in girls or increase the risk for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma in women.
? Less commonly granulosa cell tumors can secrete androgens and produce masculinization.

questions.text: The case that is being followed by the entire community is that of a young man who has claimed his rightful property. He alleges that he is the posthumous child of the late owner of a bungalow in that town. The court has begun an investigation into the matter. While claiming to be a posthumous child, he is claiming to be?

choices.text: Child delivered after death of biological mother
Child delivered after death of biological father

questions.solution:
Posthumous Child :

→ It is a child born after the death of its father, the mother being conceived by the said father.

→ Legal issues involved are: legitimacy, inheritance of property, compensation case for slander against the mother.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient, who is currently undergoing treatment for malaria has presented with the following finding. Identify which of the following drug is responsible for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Bull’s eye maculopathy

  • It is a rare dystrophy, also known as benignconcentric annular macular dystrophy (BCAMD).
  • It causes a dartboard, or ring-shaped, the pattern of damage around the macula.
  • It can be caused by chloroquine (or)hydroxychloroquine. Side effects of antimalarial drugs:
Drug Side effect
Chloroquine (4-aminoquinoline) Bull’s eye maculopathy, confusion, psychosis, agranulocytosis.
Primaquine (8-aminoquinoline ) hemolytic anemia in G6PD deficiency, leukopenia, agranulocytosis, leukocytosis, cardiac arrhythmias.
Quinine Cinchonism (constellation of symptoms): tinnitus, headache, nausea, dizziness, flushing, visual disturbances.
Tafenoquine (8-aminoquinoline) Hemolysis in G-6PD Deficieny

questions.text: A 37 year old male, came in with complaint of constant right upper back pain. On examination, you find that the pain was 2/5 in visual analogue scale for pain and decide to give medication for the same. If you prefer to give an oral medication, which of the following drugs do you think has maximum chances of absorption from gastric mucosa?
questions.solution:
• Diclofenac sodium is a weak acid and is non-ionized in the acidic medium of stomach.
  • Drugs, when in similar medium are non-ionized and lipid-soluble. Therefore, Diclofenac sodium has the maximum chances of absorption from the stomach.
  • Other drugs given in the options are weakly basic drugs that are ionized at gastric pH.

Note:

  • Most of the drugs ending with 'INE' are basic in nature like morphine, quinidine, hyoscine, atropine, tubocurarine etc.
  • Drugs forming salts with cations like sodium or potassium are acidic like diclofenac sodium, thiopentone sodium etc
  • Drugs forming salts with anions like sulphate, phosphate etc. are basic like morphine sulphate, chloroquine phosphate etc

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy with a large splenic abscess underwent successful splenectomy with the resolution of his symptoms thereafter. This patient has an increased chance of infection by all the following organisms except :
questions.solution:
Capsulated organisms can resist killing by preventing phagocytosis.
• Spleen has an important role in removing these capsulated organisms where opsonization takes place.
• Certain complements (opsonins) can attach to these organisms and once delivered to the spleen, their uptake is facilitated by complement receptors like CR1, 2. etc. present on the splenic phagocyte surface (Process known as Opsonization).
• Hence, in a splenectomized patient there is an increased risk of infection by capsulated organisms.
• Among the options, all are capsulated except S. aureus.

questions.text: Sampling is a process used in statistical analysis in which a predetermined number of observations are taken from a larger population. Given below image demonstrates which of the following sampling method ?
questions.solution:
Stratified Random Sampling

  • Population is divided into homogeneous groups/strata.
  • From the groups, sample units are drawn randomly.
  • Units drawn in probabaility proportionate to size.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man Ram Srinath is brought by his wife Shanti Devi for a general master check-up. The attending physician examined the patient and ordered all routine tests along with a D-dimer test. It is the most sensitive diagnostic test for:
questions.solution:
? D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product, a small protein fragment present in the blood after a blood clot is degraded by fibrinolysis.
? It is so named because it contains two crosslinked D fragments of the fibrinogen protein.
? D-dimer concentration may be determined by a blood test to help diagnose thrombosis. D-dimer testing is of clinical use when there is a suspicion of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE).
? In patients suspected of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), D-dimers may aid in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with complaints of fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain. The patient is having these symptoms after ingestion of meat 18hrs ago in lunch. Results from the sample sent to the lab suggested Clostridial food poisoning. What is the most common type of Clostridium responsible for such a condition?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of Clostridial food poisoning is Cl. perfringens type A.
Food poisoning by Clostridium:
? Cause -Ingestion of cold and warmed up meat dishes.
? Incubation period - 8 to 24 hours.
? Clinical feature:
? Abdominal cramps and watery diarrhea.
? Usually Absence of nausea, vomiting, or fever—are characteristic presentations of this condition.
? Self-limiting and recovery within 24–48 hours.
? Most common cause of gas gangrene- C. perfringens.
? Type A strains are the most common.
? These strains produce spores → heat resistant → produce enterotoxin (coded by gene cpe).

questions.text: Using a new technique, Hb was estimated in a blood sample. The test was repeated for 10 times. The reports were: 9.5, 9.2, 9.4, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5 and 12.1. Accurate value of Hb was estimated by standard tests to be 10.2. The new technique has:
questions.solution:
In the given question,

Mean of 10 Hb values = Sum (9.5, 9.2, 9.4, 9.6, 9.7, 9.9, 10.2, 10.3, 10.5 and 12.1)/10 = 100/10 = 10

  • Validity means getting the right results, whether positive or negative and reliability means getting the same result every time, irrespective of whether it is right or wrong.
  • Since the results obtained by test are different than the actual value of Hb, it is not valid or accurate.
  • Also, since every time we are getting different values , the test is not reliable.

questions.text: You are posted as a community medical officer in a rural place of your state and asked to find the prevalence of TB in the community with a population of 5000, number of new cases of TB is 500; old cases in the same population are 150. What is the prevalence of TB?
questions.solution:
Prevalence = total number of cases [new+old cases]/ total population x 100

= (650/5000) ×100 =13%

questions.text: You are an intern posted in Gyne opd, receiving a 28 yr old Breastfeeding mother with 6 weeks old baby, who is wanting to avoid pregnancy for a longer interval. Which of the following contraceptive options will you advice the patient?
questions.solution:
NOTE THAT THE QUESTION IS ASKING EXCEPT

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated up to six months postpartum, as they decrease breastmilk output.
  • Progesteron only pills / mini pills/ micro pills / intraceptive pills are contraceptive of choice in lactating women.
  • IUD can also be used [LNG-IUD, IUD
  • 380A, Implanon].

Absolute contraindications

  1. Cancer(breast,cervix)
  2. Liver disease( adenoma)
  3. Uterine bleeding(excessive and undiagnosed)
  4. Thromboembolism
  5. Cardiovascular disease
  6. Hyperlipidemia
  7. Pregnancy
  8. nursing mother in first 6 months

questions.text: A 27 year old female came in to your clinic with complaints of irregular periods, infertility and breast pain. After collecting relevant history, before doing the physical examination, as you suspect and consider hyperprolactinemia as your diagnosis, you ask if the patient is taking any of the following medications, except?
questions.solution:
• Hyperprolactinemia is caused by D2 blockers.
  • All the drugs listed are D2 blockers except Bromocriptine which is a D2 receptor agonist.
  • It is used in the treatment of Hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: During a certain procedure in the trial, the lawyer of the defendant asked a leading question and the opposing lawyer quickly raised an objection. The judge sustained the appeal and requested the defending lawyer to avoid leading questions as they cannot be allowed in any of the following incidents except ?
questions.solution:
Leading Question:

  • Defined Under The Indian Evidence Act Section 141
  • Any question suggesting the answer which the person putting it wishes or expects to receive is called a leading question.
  • It includes a material fact and admits of a conclusive answer by a simple ‘Yes’ or ‘No’

Leading questions not permitted in

  • Examination in chief (section 142 IEA)
  • Re-examination
  • Dying declaration

Leading questions permitted in

  • Cross-examination (section 143 IEA)
  • Dying deposition
  • Hostile witness (section 154 IEA)

Examination in chief

  • questioning of the witness by the party who has called him, to enable the witness to tell to the court by his own mouth the relevant facts of the case.
  • A question should be put to him about the relevant facts and then he should be given the fullest freedom to answer the question out of the knowledge he possesses.
  • The answer should not be suggested.
  • The question should not be framed as to suggest the answer also.
  • The question should not carry an inbuilt answer in it.

questions.text: A middle aged lady was found robbed in a room lying in a pool of blood. On forensic examination, there was an entry wound of size 2 x 2 cm on the left temporal region with tattooing and blackening around the wound. There was also an exit wound with beveling at the right temporal region. On further examination two bullet fragments were found inside the brain parenchyma. Which of the following could be used to determine the distance from which the weapon was fired?
questions.solution:
Information provided in the question

  • An entry wound of size around 2 x 2 cm on the left temporal region
  • Tattooing and blackening are present around the wound on the left temporal region
  • Exit wound with beveling at the right temporal region
  • two bullet fragments were found inside the brain parenchyma.

It is asked that among the four options viz Hair, Clothes, Bullet fragments and Blood, which one can be used to determine the distance from which the weapon was fired ie range of firing.

Now we know that following characteristics of any gunshot wound can be used to estimate the range of fire

Singeing of hair/Scorching

  • due to the escape of hot gases by the sides of the muzzle end results in singeing of hairs.

Abraded collar/abraded contused ring

Soot or smoke soiling/blackening/smudging

  • Deposition of smoke over the epidermis.
  • These particles being light, do not travel afar (for virtually all hand gun cartridges, soot is absent around the entry wound where the muzzle-to-target distance is beyond one foot)

Tattooing/peppering/stippling

  • Due to embedding of semi-burnt and/or unburnt powder particles in the dermis (patterns of tattooing are usually not to be seen around the entry wound where the muzzle-to-target distance is over four feet)

Cloths

  • Examination of clothing of the victim of firearm injury should be done for any defect made by the missile/missiles and for deposition of any firearm residue.

#blood and bullet fragments are not used for this purpose. In the given question as the wound is located on head, out of hair and clothes since hair is obviously more on suitable to calculate range.

  • Flu

questions.text: A 39 year old male patient came in to your clinic with complaints of right flank pain and right lower back pain.   • Furosemide (Loop diuretic)- Increases Ca2+ excretion and can precipitate the condition of pt.

questions.text: Therapeutic monitoring of plasma level of drug is done when the drug’s response cannot be measured. Given that, if a 56 year old male patient, known case of Lupus nephritis comes to you for treatment of a problem ‘x’ where ‘x’ could be anything, which of the following drugs would not require therapeutic dose monitoring?
questions.solution:
TDM is done in following conditions:

  • Response of a drug cannot be measured.
  • Drug should have narrow therapeutic index (TI) .
  • Drug should have inconsistent pharmacokinetics . Response can be measured in drugs like:
  • Anti-hypertensive drugs: blood pressure can be measured to see their response
  • Anti-diabetic drugs: blood sugar can measured to see their response
  • Anti-coagulants: prothrombin time can be measured to see their response.

So, answer is warfarin (anti-coagulant) as its response can be measured.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man Sonu with a history of recurrent calcium-containing renal stones presents to the emergency room with excruciating flank pain and blood in the urine. This patient is likely to have which of the following underlying disorders?
questions.solution:
The patient’s history of recurrent urolithiasis with calcium-containing stones implies a disorder in the regulation of calcium concentration.
Hyperparathyroidism is associated with increased parathormone (PTH) levels, which can produce hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria, and, ultimately, renal stones.

(option A) - Anemia of chronic disease does not produce calcium stones. The patient presents with a chronic condition and hematuria but the urinary blood lossexcruciating flank pain and blood in the urine is not usually significant enough to produce an anemic state.

(option C) - Hyperaldosteronism results in potassium depletion, sodium retention, and hypertension. Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn’s syndrome) is associated with adrenocortical adenomas in 90% of patients and is characterized by decreased renin. Secondary hyperaldosteronism results from excessive stimulation by angiotensin II that is caused by excess renin production (plasma renin-angiotensin levels are high). Neither condition is associated with renal stones.

questions.text: A 23 year old woman was examined by the medical officer post allegations of being physically and sexually assaulted by her boyfriend. To assist in confirming the allegation, the doctor began a thorough physical examination. The doctor preferred to document the abrasion wounds over contusions. All of the following are true of contusions except ?

choices.text: They may become visible several hours after injury
They may not indicate the site of trauma
The do not indicate the direction of force
They are visible immediately after an injury

questions.solution:
→ Character and manner of injury may be known from the distribution of bruise

- eg. Small bruises along with nail marks on the inner aspect of thighs of a woman may indicate sexual assault.

→ Bruises are of lesser value than abrasions because:

  • Their size may not correspond to the size of the weapon They do not indicate the direction of the applied force.
  • They may become visible after few hours to 1–2 days after the injury has happened.
  • They may appear at a distance away from the actual site of injury eg. black eye

questions.text: A 43 year old male presented with complains of double vision, weakness of eye muscle, drooping eyelids and change in his facial expression. Weakness in the skeletal muscles worsens after activity and improves after rest. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is expressed in the given condition ?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given is suggestive of Myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis is a Type II hypersensitivity reaction.

In myasthenia gravis antibodies are directed against Ach Receptors so this a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction.

Hypersensitivity: An altered state of reactivity to an ANTIGEN/HAPTEN in a sensitized host resulting in an unexpected, exaggerated reaction which is injurious to the host leading to tissue damage/disease/death.

Types of Hypersensitivity:

A → Anaphylactic hypersensitivity → TYPE I

C → Cytotoxic hypersensitivity → TYPE II

I → Immune complex mediated hypersensitivity → TYPE III

D → Delayed hypersensitivity → TYPE IV

Option 1

Type I hypersensitivity reaction:

  • Commonly called allergic or immediate hypersensitivity reaction

. →occurs in 2 phases:

1.Sensitization Phase:

→ Allergen is processed by APC & Peptides of it presented to CD4 T cells → Activates TH2cells → Releases IL4 → Activates B cells →IgEProduction → HOMOCYTOTROPISM [movement towards the mast cells].

2. Effector Phase:

Shocking Dose → Mast cell Degranulation→ primary and secondary mediators.
Option 2

Type II cytotoxic reaction is mediated by IgG antibodies directed against antigens on the cell membrane that activates complement thereby causing antibody-mediated destruction of cells.

Antibody Dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC): → used to Killing & destruction of Parasites, Tumor cells, Graft tissue. Antibody Dependent Cellular Dysfunction (ADCD)→ Auto Ab mediated

Types:

1. Stimulatory ADCD: Eg. Grave’s Disease

→ Activation of receptors takes place.

→ Auto Ab (Long Acting Thyroid stimulators LATS) produced.

→ Stimulate Thyroid to produce hormones.

2. Inhibitory ADCD: Eg. Myasthenia gravis

→ Inhibition of receptor takes place.

→ Anti Ach receptor Ab are produced.

→ Blocking of Ach receptors happens & Leads to Profound muscular weakness.
Option3

Type-III hypersensitivity reactions are as a result of excess formation of immune complexes (Ag-Ab complexes) which initiate an inflammatory response through activation of complement system leading to tissue injury:

  • Localized or Arthus reaction
  • Generalized or Systemic type III Reactions, e.g. Serum sickness.
Option4

Type-IV hypersensitivity:-

  • It is delayed type (occurs after 48–72 hours of antigen exposure).
  • Cell mediated: Characteristic cells called TDTH cells ((TH cells involved in delayed type of hypersensitivity) are the principal mediators.

questions.text: A 25y.o male presented with the sudden onset of painless watery diarrhea that quickly becomes voluminous and is often followed by vomiting. A rapid stool test was done in the patient which showed the following finding shown in the image. The selective media for the pathogen involved is:
questions.solution:
The given Gram-stained image shows visualization of flagellate bacillus of cholera
• TCBS (Thiosulfate Citrate Bile salts Sucrose Agar) is a Selective media for Vibrio.
• V. Cholerae can ferment sucrose and it produces Yellow colonies on TCBS.
• Whereas V.parahemolyticus produces green colonies on TCBS
Cultural conditions: V. cholerae is:
• Nonfastidious and strongly aerobic
• Hemodigestion on blood agar
• Growth is better in alkaline medium. The optimum pH is 8.2
• NaCl (0.5–1%) stimulates the growth, however, high concentrations of NaCl (> 6%) are inhibitory.
Culture medium:
• Enrichment broth:
- Alkaline peptone water (APW)
- Monsur’s taurocholate tellurite peptone water (pH 9.0).
• Selective media:
- Alkaline bile salt agar (BSA)
- Monsur’s gelatin taurocholate trypticase tellurite agar (GTTTA) medium
- TCBS agar (thiosulfate, citrate, bile salts, sucrose and pH of 8.6)

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presented to ER with asthenia, nausea, and choluria developing over 1 week. She was afebrile and hemodynamically stable on admission. On examination, the patient was jaundiced and had pain on upper abdominal wall palpation, with no signs of peritoneal irritation or ascites. If Acute hepatitis was diagnosed in this patient, the most common pathological change seen would be:
questions.solution:
Acute hepatitis
? Swelling of the hepatocytes called “Ballooning”.
? Presence of apoptotic hepatocytes giving rise to Councilman bodies. Apoptosis of a single hepatocyte is called ‘spotty necrosis’.
? Disruption of the lobular architecture of the liver.
? Necrosis connecting portal to portal, portal to central, central to central regions of adjacent lobules is called bridging necrosis
? Infiltration of the portal tract with inflammatory cells.
? Spilling of inflammatory cells in the adjacent parenchyma causing necrosis of adjacent cells (Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis).

questions.text: A 27 year old male was brought to the emergency department after RTA.Initial resuscitative measures were done, but despite the treatment the patient passed away. A person is said to be killed by Road traffic accident (RTA) if he dies within how many days of accident?

Road fatality

questions.text: A 10-day-old male patient, born by NSVD at term with a weight of 3kg was admitted to NICU due to fever and difficulty breathing. Blood and urine samples were obtained and cultured which showed a growth of capsulated; lens shaped; catalase oxidase positive; gram negative cocci. The virulence factors of the pathogen involved are all except:
questions.solution:
N. meningitidis
? Capsulated
? Lens shaped/half-moon shaped (diplococci with adjacent sides flattened)
? Ferments glucose and maltose
? Rarely have plasmids
? Exist in both intra and extracelular forms
? Colony—circular
? Habitat—Nasopharynx
Virulence factor of Meningococcus:
? Capsular polysaccharide: It prevents the bacteria from phagocytosis, can be typed into 13 serogroups:
- Only 5 serogroups account for the majority of cases: A, B, C, Y, and W135;
- Other capsular serotypes and non-capsulated strains (16% of isolates are not capsulated) colonize the nasopharynx of asymptomatic carriers.
? Outer membrane proteins: OMP is used to classify serogroups into serotypes.
? Lipopolysaccharide and endotoxin: Causes endothelial injury leads to:
- Increased vascular permeability leading to loss of fluid and shock
- Intravascular thrombosis leading to DIC
- Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome
- Myocardial dysfunction
? IgA proteases - Cleave mucosal IgA
? Transferrin binding protein.
? Adhesins: Mediated by OPA protein and pili.
• Option C: M protein is a Virulence factor for Streptococcus.

questions.text: A patient presented with red eyes, increased tear production, feeling of foreign body in the eyes. The diagnosis of conjunctivitis was made by a physician. Which of the following virus does not cause Conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
All the options above can cause conjunctivitis except Cytomegalovirus (CMV). It causes retinitis.

Aseptic meningitis (A7, A9)

Option 4

questions.text: A Middle aged male with complaints of bloody diarrhoea and abdominal pain visited the OPD. He had recently visited to Ghana. Stool examination revealed a cilliated protozoa. Which of the following is false about the causative organism in this condition?

choices.text: Balantidium coli is the most likely causative agent
It is the largest protozoan parasite inhabiting large intestine in man

questions.solution:
Clinical condition and stool examination results point towards Balantidium coli as the causative agent. Balantidium coli: Only ciliate protozoa and the largest causing human disease (ciliate dysentery).

Contains:

→ Peristome

→ Cytostome

→ Cytopharynx

→ Micro & Macro Nucleus

  • Largest intestinal protozoa.
  • Rotatory motility present.

Infective stage: binucleate cyst; spherical, ellipsoid, 50-75 mm, double layered cyst wall.

The invasive form is the trophozoite (image below) - 80-120 mm; two nuclei (macronucleus, micronucleus), peristome, cytostome, cytopharynx, cytopyge

Drug of Choice → TETRACYCLINE

questions.text: Attitude is defined as relatively enduring organization of beliefs around an object or subject which predisposes one to respond in a preferential manner. All of the following statements are true about 'Attitude' except?

choices.text: More or less permanent ways of behaving

questions.solution:
Opinions:

  • Views held by people on a point of dispute.
  • Are temporary, provisional
  • Are Subjective in nature

Belief:

  • Views derived from parents, grandparents and other people we respect.
  • Permanent, unstable, almost unchanging
  • Subjective in nature’

Attitude:

  • Relatively enduring organization of beliefs around an object or subject which predisposes one to respond in a preferential manner.
  • Acquired characteristics of an individual
  • Is more or less ‘permanent ways of behaving
  • Is ‘caught, not taught’
  • Is ‘objective in nature’

Value :

  • The ideals, customs, institutions of a society toward which the people of the group have an affective regard.
  • May be positive (cleanliness, freedom, or education) or negative (cruelty, crime, or blasphemy).

questions.text: A 50 year old male, came in with complaints of left sided chest pain, sweating and unexplained discomfort. Post evaluation, you diagnose the patient to have had an episode of exertional angina. Given that the patient is a known case of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia, you prescribe medications covering for the same. Which of the following anti-angina drugscan you add, especially one thatactsby inhibition of long-chain 3-ketoacyl coenzyme A thiolase?
questions.solution:
Trimetazidine

  • Antianginal drug that act by inhibiting mitochondrial long-chain 3-ketoacyl coenzyme A thiolase enzyme.
  • Reducedfatty acid metabolism and increased glucose metabolism in myocardium leading to a partial shift from FFA to glucose oxidation in the heart, which provides less ATP but requires less O2 and may therefore be beneficial in ischemia.
  • Efficient in reducing angina and increase exercise tolerance, particularly in patients with diabetes and heart failure.

questions.text: On examination of the body of the 34-year-old actor, who had allegedly committed suicide by hanging, the forensic doctor notices hypostasis(reddish-purple discoloration) in the hands, the feet, and around the genitalia of the victim. He documented the same as "Suggilation" which can also be documented as?
questions.solution:
Livor Mortis = postmortem hypostasis = postmortem lividity = postmortem staining = suggillations = vibices

  • With the cessation of circulation at the time of death, the blood gravitates into the toneless capillaries and venules in the dependent parts of the body
  • This passive pooling of blood into the dependent areas of the body, imparting purplish or reddish-purple discolouration to those areas, is known as postmortem hypostasis.
  • The distribution of hypostasis depends upon the posture of body after death. and so helpful in determining the last position of the dead.
  • In case of hanging: hypostasis will be more marked on dependent lower limbs, surrounding genitalia, hands and distal portions of the arms.
  • In case of drowning: postmortem staining is usually found on the face, the upper part of the chest, hands, lower arms, feet and lower legs

Cherry-pink or cherry-red colour: poisoning by carbon monoxide or hydrocyanic acid Chocolate or coffee-brown colour: poisoning by potassium chlorate, potassium bichromate or nitrobenzene, aniline, etc. Dark brown colour: in poisoning by phosphorus. Bright pink patches: refrigerated dead body.

questions.text: A 40 years old male patient approached the emergency department with clenching his hands over the chest and diaphoresis. ECG reveals the below-depicted image. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

questions.text: 5 years old north Indian child came to the hospital with a complaint of chronic diarrhea. On examination, the patient turned out to be positive for HLA-DQ 2 & tissue transglutaminase. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Celiac disease is the most common cause of chronic diarrhea in North India.
  • The classical presentation is small bowel diarrhoea, growth failure and anemia.
  • IgA antibody against tissue transglutaminase is an ELISA based test recommended for initial testing
  • The diagnosis of celiac disease may be made without a duodenal biopsy provided that the anti-endomysial antibody and HLA DQ2/DQ8 are positive and there is a definite response to gluten-free diet.

Associated with Blunt trauma

questions.text: 55 years old patient Lakha Singh presented to OPD with complaints of weakness and fatigue, dyspnea on lying down, and palpitations. Symptoms aggravate at night time when he tries to sleep in the bed. He gives h/o of Rheumatic heart disease in past. O/E - BP = 116/ 80 mm Hg, Pulse = 86bpm, elevated JVP, Hyperdynamic Apex beat with apical thrill on palpation. ECHO was done which revealed Mitral regurgitation. A diagnosis of Chronic Mitral regurgitation was made. Which of the following is false regarding Chronic Mitral Regurgitation?
questions.solution:
• Narrow split S1 is a feature of mitral Stenosis. Choice D is incorrect.
  • In case of Mitral Regurgitation,the extra blood that flows into left atrium has to come back to left ventricle during diastolic phase.
  • This leads to mid diastolic murmur. Choice A is Correct.
  • Due to early A2, wide Split S2 is heard. Choice B is correct
  • The most characteristic auscultatory finding is grade 3/6 pansystolic murmur. Choice C is correct.
  • Chronic MR features
    • S1 = soft
    • S2 = Wide split = Early A2
    • S3++
    • S4++ = extreme LV dilatation
    • Opening snap = absent
    • Primary murmur = Pansystolic = Apex = High pitch = Radiating to Interscapular area or Axilla
    • Secondary murmur = severe MR = Mid-diastolic murmur

questions.text: You are a Medical officer posted in casualty and receiving a patient of severe head injury. After initial resuscitative measures, patient was shifted to ward where the patient complained of hearing loss(Conductive). On examination, tympanic membrane was normal and mobile. Most Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In post head injury, the conductive deafness may occur due to:

  • Fracture temporal bone (more commonly longitudinal) extending to external canal: tympanic membrane is frequently torn and inner ear is spared.
  • Blood or CSF in external and middle ear.
  • Damage to ossicle (most frequent being incudo-stapedial joint) resulting in more severe and permanent conductive deafness.
  • Aseptic necrosis of long process of incus can lead to late conductive deafness.

In the Question it is given:

  • Tympanic membrane is normal and mobile: In hemotympanum
  • tympanic membrane will appear red/blue (due to presence of blood pigments) so it is ruled out. Otosclerosis and EAC sclerosis do not occur in case of head injury and hence they are ruled out.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of lung. All of the following can be considered oncologic emergencies in this patient, except?

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with a history of 3 months of menorrhagia. USG showing 2 cm submucosal fibroid. Which of the following is the first line of management?

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child was brought by his mother with a c/o mass in the abdomen. The parent’s medical history was insignificant. He was the second child of a healthy nonconsanguineous parent. In laboratory tests, serum catecholamines, urinary vanillyl mandelic acid, and homovanillic acid levels were found to be elevated. CT scan was done which revealed a mass of 4x2x2cm in size just above the kidneys. All of the following statements about the diagnosis of this case are true except:
