questions.solution:
A 2-year-old male child with elevated levels of urinary catecholamine metabolites is suggestive of a tumour arising from adrenal medulla - Neuroblastoma

NEUROBLASTOMA

  • Most common extracranial solid tumour in infants and children
  • Arise from neural crest cells
  • Malignant neoplasm of the sympathetic nervous system
  • Third most common paediatric malignancy
  • Over 80% of cases present before the age of 4 years and peak incidence is 2 yrs
  • Most common site:65% occur in abdomen with 50% localised to the adrenal medulla, neck (5%), chest (20%) or pelvis (5%)

Clinical features

  • Asymptomatic
  • Constitutional symptoms
  • Enlarging mass, Pain, Abdominal distension
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Respiratory distress
  • Bladder or bowel disturbance Horner syndrome
  • Periorbital swelling and proptosis (raccoon eyes)
  • Blueberry muffin syndrome (blue subcutaneous nodules)
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes (intractable diarrhea)
  • Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome

Diagnosis

  • Elevated levels of
    • -urinary catecholamines and their metabolites (vanillyl mandelic acid or homovanillic acid)
    • - lactate dehydrogenase (>1500U/ml)
    • - ferritin (>142ng/mL)
    • - neuron specific enolase (>100ng/mL)
  • Histology - Undifferentiated small round blue cells
  • Modified Shimda classification - helps to predict prognosis

TREATMENT

  • Localized neuroblastoma: Excision
  • Unresectable tumor: Biopsy, initially treated by chemotherapy and radiotherapy followed by surgical resection of residual tumor
  • Disseminated disease: Chemotherapy (Cyclophosphamide, vincristine, dacarbazine, doxorubicin, Cisplatin)

questions.text: A 37-year-old male known case of peptic ulcer disease on irregular treatment came to the OPD with complaints of hematemesis. Endoscopy revealed the site of bleeding and electrocoagulation was done. According to Forrest classification, a high risk of rebleeding is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Rebleeding risk is high in all of the above except in case of adherent clots

The Forrest Classification for Endoscopic findings and Rebleeding Risks in Peptic Ulcer Disease:

Classification Rebleeding risk
Grade Ia Active pulsatile bleeding High
Grade Ib Active nonpulsatile bleeding High
Grade IIa Nonbleeding visible vessel High
Grade IIb Adherent clot Intermediate
Grade IIC Ulcer with black spot Low
Grade III Clean nonbleeding ulcer Low

Endoscopic therapy is recommended in cases of active bleeding as well as for a visible vessel (Forrest I-IIa)

For Forrest IIb, the clot is removed and the underlying lesion evaluated

Ulcer with a clean base or a black spot, secondary to hematin deposition are generally not treated endoscopically

questions.text: A 60 year old man came with complains of headache & On Ophthalmic examination optic disc swelling in the right eye and optic atrophy in left eye optic atrophy were noted. Patient is most likely suffering from
questions.solution:
This is a case of pseudo foster Kennedy syndrome.-

  • It is characterized by occurrence of unilateral papilloedema associated with raised intracranial pressure (due to any cause) and a pre-existing optic atrophy (due to any cause) on the other side.
  • It is caused most commonly by bilateral sequential anterior ischemic optic neuropathy.

Foster-Kennedy syndrome.-

  • It is associated with olfactory or sphenoidal meningioma and frontal lobe tumors (anterior fossa tumours)
  • In this condition, there occurs pressure optic atrophy on the side of lesion and papilloedema on the other side (due to raised intracranial pressure).
  • It is classically associated with frontal lobe meningioma which is absent in above case.

Sphenoid wing meningiomas are common in 5th decade of life in women whereas the clinical scenario provided is of 60 year old male patient

questions.text: A female patient with Turner syndrome came to the hospital with complaints of exertional dyspnea associated with head pounding sensation. On further examination, the patient presents with mid-diastolic murmur which described as Austin flint murmur. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a classic case of Aortic regurgitation
  • The patient is a known case of Turner syndrome who is prone to have bicuspid aortic valve which is one of the causes for aortic regurgitation
  • Other causes include:
    • Infective endocarditis / SABE: perforation
    • RHD (Rheumatic Heart Disease)
    • Myxomatous degeneration of valve
    • Syphilis
    • Ankylosing spondylitis
    • Aortic root dilation
      • Aortitis
      • Aortic dissection
      • HTN
      • Cystic medial necrosis
      • Marfan syndrome
  • The patient presents with following symptoms
    • Uncomfortable sensation in supine position
    • Head pounding sensation
    • Development of exertional dyspnea
    • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
    • Orthopnea / diaphoresis
    • Angina – May be present at rest or on exertion
  • Murmurs of AR
    • Early Diastolic murmur→ Main murmur
    • Mid Diastolic murmur→ Austin Flint murmur (RHD)
    • Ejection systolic murmur→ If AS is co-existent

questions.text: A pediatric patient came to your hospital with complaints of short stature. No other significant complaints were present in this patient. On examination, the patient’s bone age is similar to that of chronological age. Which of the following is responsible for the short stature?
questions.solution:
• Only type of short stature in which bone age is similar to that of chronological age is familial short stature
  • No signs of delayed puberty are seen in familial short stature
  • In constitutional delay, the growth is delayed than normal with delayed puberty.
  • Short extremities were seen in achondroplasia and cretinism

questions.text: A 10 years old girl came to the hospital with complaints of polyarthritis associated with fever. ECG reveals 1st-degree heart block. 3 weeks ago, patient got symptoms of sore throat which was not treated efficiently. The patient also gives a family history of rheumatic heart disease. You are suspecting Rheumatic heart disease in this patient. Which of the following criteria are included under major category in the criteria used in this patient?
questions.solution:
• This is a classic case of rheumatic heart disease.
  • The above-mentioned patient comes under Moderate risk category of Jones criteria
  • The most recent revision of the Jones criteria requires the clinician to determine if the patient is from a setting or population known to experience low rates of ARF.
  • For that group, there is a set of “low-risk” criteria; for all others, there is a set of more sensitive criteria.

questions.text:
Match the following tumor with their place of origin:





Chondroblastoma
Giant cell tumor
Osteosarcoma
Osteoid osteoma




Epiphysis
Metaphysis
Diaphysis
Adamantinoma
questions.solution:
• MOST COMMON SITE OF PRIMARY BONE TUMORS (Epiphyseal)
  • Occurrence of bone tumors based on part of the bone
  • Epiphysis
    • Chondroblastoma → Before skeletal maturity; (+) Calcification
    • Giant cell tumor→ After Skeletal maturity
  • Metaphysis (most common location for tumor/ infection)

  • Diaphysis
    • Osteoidosteoma
    • Adamantinoma→ Soap bubble appearance
    • Ewing’s sarcoma

questions.text: 7 years old female came to the hospital with an episode of hematuria associated with bilateral hearing loss. Ophthalmology examination revealed anterior lenticonus. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is a case of alport syndrome – X-linked hereditary disease.
  • Mutations in the gene encoding alpha subunit of collagen IV (COL4A) result in persistent microscopic hematuria, moderate proteinuria and progressive kidney failure.
  • A significant proportion show high frequency sensorineural deafness; ocular defects (lenticonus, cataract, macular changes) are often associated.
  • Ultrastructural examination of renal biopsy shows variable thickness of glomerular basement membrane with lengths of marked attenuation to areas of lamination.
  • Therapy is supportive, including the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors.

questions.text: A 47 year old chronic smoker came to your clinic with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx. Laryngoscopy revealed the features depicted in the below image. Which of the following sites will be the most common site of distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
• Most common site of locoregional metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is Lymph nodes.
  • Most common site of distant metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is Lung.
  • Most common site of laryngeal carcinoma is Glottic carcinoma.
  • Most common type of laryngeal carcinoma is Squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: A Mitral stenosis patient has developed pulmonary artery hypertension. Which of the following auscultatory findings may be heard?
questions.solution:
• With severe pulmonary hypertension, a pansystolic murmur produced by functional TR may be audible along the left sternal border.
  • This murmur is usually louder during inspiration and diminishes during forced expiration (Carvallo’s sign).
  • When the CO is markedly reduced in MS, the typical auscultatory findings, including the diastolic rumbling murmur, may not be detectable (silent MS), but they may reappear as compensation is restored.
  • The Graham Steel murmur of PR, a high-pitched, diastolic, decrescendo blowing murmur along the left sternal border, results from dilation of the pulmonary valve ring and occurs in patients with mitral valve disease and severe pulmonary hypertension.
  • Choice 1 is wrong because it is written crescendo while in PAH early diastolic decrescendo murmur occurs.
  • Choice 2 is ruled out as it is seen in AS
  • PAH in MS leads to decompensation of RV. The dilated RV leads to TR and a pansystolic murmur will result.
  • Choice 4 is seen in Mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male who lost his father came to your clinic and says that he has cholelithiasis. Ultrasound revealed no significant findings for gallstones. The patient refused to accept the report and he is still adamant about his diagnosis. Which of the following is described here?
questions.solution:
• Hypochondriasis: Transformation of reproach toward others arising from bereavement, loneliness, or unacceptable aggressive impulses, into self-reproach in the form of preoccupation with disease diagnosis
  • Somatization disorder: The defensive conversion of psychic derivatives into bodily symptoms; tendency to react with somatic rather than psychic manifestations.
  • Body dysmorphic disorder: Preoccupation with an imagined defect in body appearance
  • Denial: Psychotic denial of external reality, unlike repression, affects perception of external reality more than perception of internal reality

questions.text: A 35-year-old female Presents to OPD with pain in the Hand involving Distal Interphalangeal joint, Proximal Interphalangeal joint, 1st carpometacarpal joint. There is sparing of Meta Carpo-Phalangeal and wrist joints. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario has classical features of Osteoarthritis
  • Osteoarthritis characteristically involves distal interpha­langeal joint (Heberden’s node), proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard’s node), 1st carpometacarpal joint (base of thumb) of hand with sparing of metacarpophalangeal joint and wrist joint.

Osteoarthritis Rheumatoid Arthritis Psoriatic Arthritis (Caspar Criterion)
Joints Involved PIP, DIP and 1st CMC (carpometacarpal) joints PIP, MCP, Wrist DIP, PIP and any joint
Joints Spared MCP (Metacarpo - phalangeal), Wrist and Ankle DIP joint usually

questions.text: A 44-year-old male having a long history of cigarette smoking presented with gangrene of left foot. Amputation of the left foot was done. Representative sections from the specimen revealed the presence of arterial thrombus with neutrophilic infiltrate in the arterial wall. The inflammation also extended into the neighboring veins and nerves. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
BUERGER’S DISEASE (Thromboangiitis obliterans)

  • Segmental inflammatory disease, affecting small and medium-sized arteries in upper and lower extremities
  • Inflammatory process involves neighboring veins and nerves
  • Typically seen in young, male smokers (not females and non-smokers)
  • Thrombus contain micro abscess.
  • Characterized by triad of intermittent claudication, Raynaud’s phenomenon, migrated superficial vein thrombophlebitis

questions.text: An 75 year old, diabetic male presents with painful ear discharge and edema of the external auditory canal associated with facial palsy & not responding to antibiotics. An increased uptake on technetium bone scan is noted. The most probable diagnosis is

choices.text: Infective disease of the middle ear
Malignancy of nasopharynx with Eustachian tube obstruction

questions.solution:
An elderly diabetic patient

+

Painful ear discharge All are highly suggestive of Malignant OtitisExterna

+

Facial N palsy

+

No Response to treatment

+

Decreased uptake on Technetium bone scan

  • Gold standard for diagnosis of malignant otitis externa is technetium 99 scan
  • In refractory cases of otitisexterna if it is not responding to antibiotics even after 7–10 days of treatment always suspect malignant otitisexterna
  • M/c organism causing malignant otitisexterna is Pseudomonas

questions.text: A male patient came to the emergency room with a complaint of difficulty in breathing. On examination, the patient presents with high pitched heart sound and on deep inspiration, the JVP rises and the blood pressure falls more than 10 mmHg and presents with minimal ascites. Chest X-ray reveals characteristic “Egg in a cup appearance”. The patient has a past history of pulmonary tuberculosis. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of constrictive pericarditis
  • This disorder results when the healing of an acute fibrinous or serofibrinous pericarditis or the resorption of a chronic pericardial effusion is followed by obliteration of the pericardial cavity with the formation of granulation tissue.
  • It is mostly due to the post sequalae of Tuberculous pericarditis or pyopericardium
  • Symptoms of constrictive pericarditis include
    • Dyspnea
    • Pulmonary edema
    • Ascites
    • Low cardiac output
    • Pedal edema
  • High pitched heart sound in the question describes pericardial shudder which usually mimics S3 sound
  • JVP rises on deep inspiration describes kussmaul sign which is seen typically in constrictive pericarditis
  • Blood pressure falls more than 10 mmHg is known as Pulsusparadoxus, though rare can occur in constrictive pericarditis
  • Chest X-ray reveals Egg in a cup appearance in constrictive pericarditis
  • Egg on side appearance describes Transposition of great arteries.

questions.text: A primigravida presents with itching all over her body at 32 weeks of pregnancy. Investigations reveal a diagnosis of intrahepatic cholestasis. What is the ideal time for termination of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
• Delivery should be induced at 37–38 weeks due to increased risk of fetal mortality at later gestation
  • ICP includes pruritus with a characteristic pattern of distribution, with palms and soles of the feet especially affected, together with elevation of total serum bile acids (SBA) and/or transaminases, and absence of other liver disease to which these manifestations can be attributed.
  • Time of presentation: Late second or early third trimester of pregnancy.
  • UDCA is the DOC for this condition.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination she has normal stature, however, there is no breast development and no pubic or axillary hair. Which of the following may be a probable cause?
questions.solution:
Testicular feminization is a syndrome of androgen insensitivity, characterized by a normal 46 XY genotype; normal female phenotype during childhood; tall stature; and “normal” breast development with absence of axillary and pubic hair.

Gonadal dysgenesis (e.g., 45X Turner syndrome) is characterized by short stature and absence of pubertal development; in these girls, the ovaries are either absent or streak gonads that are non-functional.

Kallmann syndrome (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism) should be suspected in patients of normal stature with delayed or absent pubertal development, especially when associated with the classic finding of anosmia. These individuals have a structural defect of the CNS involving the hypothalamus and the olfactory bulbs. The hypothalamus does not secrete GnRH in normal pulsatile fashion, if at all.

questions.text: A 50 years old male COVID-19 positive patient develops difficulty in breathing. You are suspecting Pleural effusion. All of the following describes that the characteristics of this pleural effusion are secondary to COVID-19 infection except?

choices.text: Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds the normal upper limit for serum LDH

questions.solution:
• This is a classic example of exudative pleural effusion
  • A transudative pleural effusion occurs when systemic factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid are altered. Examples are left ventricular failure and cirrhosis.
  • An exudative pleural effusion occurs when local factors that influence the formation and absorption of pleural fluid are altered Examples are bacterial pneumonia, malignancy, viral infection, and pulmonary embolism
  • When one of the following characters are met, it is classified as Exudative pleural effusion
    • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
    • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
    • Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds the normal upper limit for serum LDH
  • If not, they are classified under transudate pleural effusion
  • However, these criteria are subjective for clinical correlation

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain during her menstrual cycles. The physician has diagnosed her with primary dysmenorrhea after evaluation. Which of the following statement is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: No clinical significant pelvis pathology is found
Menorrhagia and dyspareunia are associated with this type of dysmenorrhea
Endometriosis & PID are important causes of primary dysmenorrhea

questions.solution:
Primary dysmenorrhea

  1. The pain begins a few hours before Or just after the onset of a menstrual period & may last 48 to 72 hrs
  2. No pelvic pathology
  3. No systemic symptoms
  4. Seen in normal woman

Secondary dysmenorrhea

  1. 3-4 days prior to menstruation and last throughout periods
  2. Associated with pelvic pathology m/c endometriosis
  3. Systemic symptoms are seen

Membranous dysmenorrhoea

  1. Fibrinolytic system in uterus is responsible for less/non-clumping of blood
  2. Total absence of this system endometrium shed like cast of endometrial cavity

On examination, tympanic membrane is normal and audiogram shows a bilateral conductive deafness. Impedance audiometry shows As type of curve and acoustic reflexes are absent. All constitute part of treatment, except:
questions.solution:
Bilateral conductive hearing loss

+

+

As type of impedance auditometry curve

Gentamicin is used to treat Meniere's disease. Rest all options are managements for otosclerosis

questions.text: A 26-year-old G2P1L1 female(Rh-negative pregnancy) presents to you for a routine antenatal checkup. Based on current obstetrics practice, what is the best test for monitoring sensitized Rh-negative mothers?

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery Doppler wave forms

questions.solution:
Middle cerebral artery doppler wave forms

  • Best test for monitoring senstitized Rh negative mother is
  • Serial Doppler study of middle cerebral artery (MCA)-peak systolic velocity (PSV) is the mainstay to assess fetal anemia.
  • A value >1.5 multiples of the median (MOMs) for the corresponding gestational age, predicts moderate to severe fetal anemia.
  • This value (between 24 weeks and 35 weeks of gestation), is an indication for cordocentesis and fetal transfusion or delivery

questions.text: 2 years old male patient came to the hospital with complaints of painless, loose red currant jelly stools. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Meckel’sdiverticulum:
  • Meckel diverticulum is the most common congenital anomaly of the GI tract
  • Caused by the incomplete obliteration of the omphalomesenteric duct
  • “Rule of 2s”:
    • Found in approximately 2% of the general population
    • Usually located 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve
    • Approximately 2 inches in length o Can contain 2 types of ectopic tissue (pancreatic or gastric)
    • Generally present before the age of 2 years
    • Found twice as commonly in females
  • Asymptomatic/ presents as melena (acid-secreting mucosa that causes intermittent painless rectal bleeding by ulceration of the adjacent normal ileal mucosa)

questions.text: A 55 years old man came with the chief complaint of swelling in upper half of the body, numerous tortuous veins on the anterior chest wall. On examination, Dilated neck veins, Cyanosis, and edema on the face, neck, and upper trunk - Aggravated by supine position as well as by bilateral arm elevation. Patient is a known smoker with a history of 15 pack-years, History of loss of appetite, weight loss & hemoptysis – 1 episode. Which of the following will be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SUPERIOR VENA CAVA SYNDROME

  • It is one of the Structural-obstructive oncologic emergencies
  • It is the clinical manifestation of superior vena cava (SVC) obstruction, with severe reduction in venous return from the head, neck, and upper extremities.
  • Clinical presentation
    • Dilated neck veins
    • Collateral veins over the anterior chest wall
    • Edema of the face, arms, neck, chest and plethora
    • Cyanosis
    • Aggravated by supine position
    • Pemberton’s sign – Aggravation by bilateral arm elevation
  • Tumors related
    • Lung cancer
    • Lymphoma
    • Metastasis
  • Treatment – usually symptomatic and treatment for malignancy
  • Tumor-lysis syndrome is treatment related oncologic emergencies
  • Hypersensitivity reactions in malignancy patients is usually related to the drugs used in the treatment of the patients.
  • Pulmonary tuberculosis is not associated with the swelling of the upper half of the body
  • Hemoptysis can also be associated with lung malignancies

questions.text: 65 years old male with uncontrolled diabetes present to the hospital with dark, necrotic nasal turbinates associated with dull sinus pain and fever. On examination, the patient presents with decreased ocular motion and chemosis. There is a recent history of hospitalization in ICU for 1 month. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
RhinocerebralMucormycosis

  • Patients present with low-grade fever, dull sinus pain, diplopia, decreased mental status, decreased ocular motion, chemosis, proptosis, dusky or necrotic nasal turbinates, and necrotic hard-palate lesions that respect the midline.
  • Indi­viduals with diabetes or immunocompromising conditions such as solid organ transplants or hematologic malignancies are at risk for invasive Rhinocerebral Mucormycosis

Lemierre’s syndrome:

  • Jugular septic thrombophlebitis caused by Fuso­bacterium necrophorum
  • It is associated with metastatic infectious emboli primarily to the lung but sometimes to the liver or other organs and sepsis, with mortality rates of >15%

questions.text: A patient of a motor vehicle accident was admitted to the casualty. He does not speak but moans every now and then, eyes are closed but open to pain, the right limb is not moving but the left limb shows movement to pain. Both the legs are in extended posture. What will be the GCS score?
questions.solution:
E2+V2+M5=GCS is 9.

Components of GCS

Eye opening Verbal response Verbal response

E4 → Spontaneous

E3 → To loud voice

E2 → To pain

E1 → No response

V5→ Oriented

V4→ Disoriented/confused

V3→ Inappropriate word

V2→ Incomprehensible sound

V1→ No response

M6→ Patients obeys command

M5→ localizes pain

M4→ Withdrawal to pain

M3→ Abnormal flexion posturing

M2→ Extension posturing

M1→ No response

Maximum GCS score – 15 (E4 V5 M6)

→ Minimum GCS score – 3 (E1 V1 M1)

→ Best indicator of outcome - Motor response

→ On the basis of GCS score

  • 13 -15 → Mild head injury
  • 9-12 → Moderate head injury
  • ≤8 → Severe head injury

→ VT is used for patients

  • Incubated
  • With Tracheostomy

→ Score given for VT = 1T (for example – if E4 V1T M6, Score is 11T)

questions.text: A woman undergoes radical hysterectomy for Stage Ib Cervical cancer. On histopathological examination, it is found that cancer extends to lower body of uterus. What is the next management?

choices.text: Repeat surgery for further disease reduction

questions.solution:
• In Ca Endometrium, the involvement of the cervix is stage II,
  • But in Ca cervix, involvement of the uterus does not change the staging. It’s considered natural progression of the cancer.
  • Here since a radical surgery has already been done, the patient only requires observation and follow up

questions.text: Which is the given disease correctly corresponds to the given fluorescein angiography image:
questions.solution:
This fluorescein angiogram shows multiple leaking points corresponding to white punctate spots in the picture.

This is characteristic of proliferative diabetic retinopathy in which the newly formed vessels are leaky leading to spillage of fluorescein dye.

Birdshot retinopathy (HLA- A29) - is an uncommon idiopathic chronic bilateral disease predominantly affecting middle-aged women presenting with insidious impairment of central vision associated with photopsia and floaters.
Familial dominant drusen- Drusen are slightly elevated , yellowish white, extracellular deposits located at the interface between RPE and bruchs membrane.

questions.text: Inspect the following USG picture of fetal umbilical artery with a doppler window and opine.
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of absent diastolic flow as there is no flow visible above baseline during diastole.

Absent end diastolic flow in umbilical artery is suggestive of severe fetal compromise.

Management involves strict fetal surveillance, antenatal steroids till 34 weeks or occurrence of reversal of EDF (whichever is earlier) after which pregnancy should be terminated

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at 11 weeks of gestational age has a blood pressure reading of 150/100 mm Hg obtained during a routine visit. The patient denies any headache, visual changes, nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Her repeat BP is 160/90 mm Hg, and urinalysis is negative for protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mmHg before pregnancy or diagnosedbefore 20 weeksof gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

The average prevalence of hypertension in women aged 18 to 39 years is approximately 5-7 percent.

questions.text: A woman presents with third-degree uterocervical descent. All of the following structures are responsible for maintaining the normal position of the uterus, except?
questions.solution:
DeLancey level of support.

Level I —Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments/Mackenrodt support the uterus and vaginal vault

Level II — Formed by Paravaginal tissue and their attachment to levator ani muscles and white line.

Level III— Made by Perineal body and muscles attached to it. Includes Levator ani muscle.

questions.text: A 54-yrs-old woman undergoes a laparotomy because of a pelvic mass. At exploratory laparotomy, a unilateral ovarian neoplasm is discovered that is accompanied by a large omental metastasis. Frozen section diagnosis confirms metastatic serous cystadenocarcinoma. The most appropriate intraoperative course of action is: -

choices.text: Excision of the omental metastasis and ovarian cystectomy
Excision of the omental metastasis and unilateral oophorectomy
Omentectomy, total abdominal hysterectomy, and bilateral salpingo oophorectomy

questions.solution:
The patient in the question has advanced stage ovarian malignancy (stage IIIC) MANAGEMENT OF OVARIAN EPITHELIAL CANCER

EARLY Low risk Stage 1A, 1B, low grade Surgical staging
High risk Stage 1C, high grade Surgical staging + adjuvant chemotherapy
ADVANCED Stage II, III, IV Maximal cytoreduction + adjuvant chemotherapy

STEPS OF COMPREHENSIVE SURGICAL STAGING

  • Vertical midline incision
  • Ascitic fluid for cytology
  • If no ascites: take peritoneal washings
  • Biopsy of suspicious lesions and diaphragm
  • Omentectomy
  • Retroperitoneal lymph node evaluation

IMPORTANT POINTS

  • Maximal cytoreduction: means removal of entire pelvic tumor + resection of metastasis
  • Optimal debulking: less than 1 cm of residual lesion
  • Fertility sparing surgery (unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy): Stage 1A with low grade, Bordeline tumors
  • Neo adjuvant chemotherapy: Stage III and IV with massive ascites, massive pleural effusion, unresectable tumor. It increases chances of optimal debulking

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came to your clinic for mental health counseling. In a conversation, the patient gives a statement “The patient says that his wife has been replaced by someone”. Which of the following is described here?
questions.solution:
• The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an impostor.
  • Fregoli syndrome - The delusion that persecutors or familiar persons can assume the guise of strangers
  • Othello syndrome is known as delusion of infidelity
  • Declerambault syndrome is known as delusion of Erotomaniac delusion.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with lump of size 5x4cm in the right breast upper outer quadrant. FNAC of the lump revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. She subsequently underwent Patey’s modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following structures is preserved during the procedure?
questions.solution:
In Patey’s modified mastectomy, pectoralis major is preserved

Modified Radical mastectomy

Removal of level I,II,III axillary lymph nodes withpreservation of pectoralis major muscleand medial (anterior thoracic) pectoral nerve

Anatomic boundaries:

Anterior margin of latissimus dorsi muscle laterally Midline of sternum medially Subclavius muscle superiorly 2 to 3cm inferior to the inframammary fold inferiorly

Variants of MRM
Auchincloss Procedure Removes all breast tissue, nipple-areola complex, skin and level I & II axillary lymph nodes
PATEY’S modification Pectoralis minor is divided (usually at its insertion in the coracoid process and removed to allow complete dissection of level III axillary lymphnodes
Scanlon’s Modification Pectoralis minor is divided instead of removing. Division of pectoralis minor allows complete removal of level III axillary lymph nodes

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is on aspirin, ACE inhibitor, nitrates, and beta-blockers for chronic stable angina. Since the new year party, he is having long-lasting angina pain for the past 3 days. ECG was normal and Troponin I levels are normal. Which is the best management of this patient?

choices.text: Admit and observe for rising of cardiac biomarkers
Increase dose of long-acting nitrates and manage as outpatient

questions.solution:
• The patient is a known case of chronic stable angina and has presented with the development of unstable angina since angina episodes have become more pronounced and more frequent.
  • Antithrombotic therapy with heparin, abciximab, and intravenous beta blocker is recommended.
  • TIMIscore is calculated subsequently to decide the need for revascularization procedure.
  • Thrombolysis is contraindicated in unstable angina.

questions.text: 30 years old male came to the hospital with complaints of a cricket ball hitting directly into his eye which results the below-depicted CT scan image. The patient subsequently develops diplopia and upward gaze. Which of the following muscles is responsible for diplopia?
questions.solution:
• This is a case of blow-out fracture of orbital floor.
  • A forced duction test, where the muscular attachment of the inferior oblique is grasped with forceps and manipulated to determine passive ocular mobility, is performed to ensure that there is not inferior rectus entrapment.
  • If there is entrapment, this would also result in diplopia with upward gaze.
  • The pathophysiology of orbital blow-out fractures is (a) hydraulic from increased intraocular pressure or (b) buckling from direct bone conduction.
  • This requires surgical intervention if there is a defect of >2 cm2 or >50% of the floor with herniation.
  • Floor is the weakest wall of orbit
  • Thinnest wall - Medial wall / Lamina papyracea
  • Orbit hangs in the maxillary antrum – Tear drop sign
  • Treatment – Orbital exploration and reinforcement of the floor with mesh

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct about acute coronary syndrome?

Unstable angina comes under Non-ST segment elevation acute coronary syndrome
Gradual Intraluminal narrowing of the arteries is one of the pathophysiology for acute coronary syndrome
Stable angina is also included under acute coronary syndrome
Elevation of the cardiac biomarkers is helpful in differentiating unstable angina
questions.solution:
• Stable angina is not included under acute coronary syndrome.
  • Rest all other statements are correct Acute coronary syndrome
  • It is commonly classified into two groups to facilitate evaluation and management of the patient
    • Patients with ST-segment elevation (STEMI) in their ECG
    • Patients with non- ST-segment elevation in their ECG
  • The patients with non-ST segment elevation in their ECG include
    • NSTEMI (Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction)
    • Unstable angina
  • It is caused by an imbalance between myocardial oxygen supply and demand resulting from one or more of the following four processes that lead to thrombus formation
  1. Disruption of an unstable coronary plaque due to plaque rupture, erosion, or a calcified protruding nodule that leads to intracoronary thrombus formation and an inflammatory response
  2. Coronary arterial vaso­constriction
  3. Gradual intraluminal narrowing
  4. Increased myocardial oxygen demand produced by conditions such as fever, tachycardia, and thyrotoxicosis in the presence of fixed epicardial coronary obstruction

questions.text: A 27 year old male presents with severe congestion, photophobia and deep anterior chamber in the right eye. Left eye is normal.He also had lower back ache for a long time and for which he usually took over the counter drugs. X-ray pelvis was done which revealed sacroilitis. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
SIGNS OF ANTERIOR UVEITIS:

Male pt. presents with severe congestion, photophobia, and deep anterior chamber With Sacroiliitis , so the most common Dx is Ankylosing spondylitis.

Ankylosingspondylitis is the 2nd m/c cause for Anterior Uveitis

  • Ankylosing spondylitis.-
  • M:F= 3:1
  • HLA-B27 +ve in 95% of individuals
  • Sacroiliitis with Enthesitis is the earliest manifestations with Varying Degrees of Peripheral joint Involvement
  • M/C Extra articular Manifestastion-Uveitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female came to the casualty with a history of massive hematemesis. The patient was hypotensive and tachycardic with hemoglobin levels of 9gm/dL. The patient was resuscitated and endoscopy was done. The patient was diagnosed to have Dieulafoy’s lesion. Which of the following best describes the diagnosis?

choices.text: Aberrant vessel in the sub mucosa that bleeds from a mucosal defect

questions.solution:
DIEULAFOY'S GASTRIC LESION

  • Caused by an abnormally large (1-3 mm)Q , tortuous artery coursing through the submucosa
  • Erosion of the gastric mucosa overlying these vessels leads to haemorrhage
  • Occurs6-10 cm from the GE junction, generally in 'fundus' near the cardia along lesser curvatureQ

Diagnosis

  • Endoscopy is the diagnostic modality of choice

Treatment:

  • Initial attempts at endoscopic control are often successfulQ.
  • In cases that fail endoscopic therapy, angiographic coil embolization can be successfulQ
  • If these approaches are unsuccessful, surgical intervention may be necessary

questions.text: A 25-years-old female presents with High-Grade Pyrexia for ten days, develops acute pain in the periumbilical region spreading all over the abdomen. On further examination, the patient was found to have bradycardia and leucopenia. What would be the most likely cause?

choices.text: Perforation peritonitis due to intestinal tuberculosis
Generalized peritonitis due to appendicular perforation

questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Enteric Fever or Typhoid

  • It is caused by Salmonella typhi or paratyphi .
  • Typhoid is the MC cause of Ileal perforation in tropical countries (India)
  • Fever and abdominal pain are hallmark symptoms
  • Non-specific symptoms: Headache, cough, sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, fatigue
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding and intestinal perforation most commonly occur in the third and fourth week of illness

Characteristic signs

  • Rose spots, hepatosplenomegaly, epistaxis, leucopenia with shift to left
  • Relative bradycardia despite of high fever

Pathology

  • Ulceration and necrosis of Ileocecal Peyer’s patches
  • The ulcer is parallel to the long axis of the gut and is usually situated in the lower ileum (Longitudinal ulcers)
  • Perforation of a typhoid ulcer characteristically occurs during the third week of the illness
TB is Less likely as History doesn't mention Low Grade fever, Night Sweating, Weight loss .Appendicular perforation is an acute condition with Shifting of pain to Right Illiac Fossa.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy brought to the hospital with alleged history of road traffic accident sustained severe head injury and lost consciousness. In the emergency department, the patient GCS – 10 (E2V4M4), BP – 140/90 mm hg, PR – 110/min. Non-contrast CT scan revealed below-depicted image. Which of the following foramen is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with Epiduralhematoma
  • The artery involved in epidural hematoma is middle meningeal artery
  • The middle meningeal artery is a branch of maxillary artery which enters the skull through Foramen spinosum.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented with a suspected diagnosis of suppurative labyrinthitis. A positive Rinne’s test and positive fistula test was recorded on initial examination. The patient refused treatment, and returned to the emergency department after 2 weeks complaining of deafness in the affected ear. On examination, fistula test was observed be negative. What is the likely expected finding on repeating the Rinne test.
questions.solution:
• In the question: Patient was suffering from suppurative labyrinthitis which was not treated and led to total loss of hearing i.e. severe SNHL.
  • In severe SNHL: Rinne’s test is false negative and because labyrinth is dead. Fistula test is negative.
  • False negative Rinne test occurs in case of severe SNHL because patient does not perceive any sound of tuning fork by air conduction but responds to bone conduction due to intracranial transmission of sound from opposite healthy ear.

Fistula Test

  • The basis of this test is to induce nystagmus by producing pressure changes in the external canal which are then transmitted to the labyrinth.
  • Stimulation of the labyrinth results in nystagmus and vertigo. Normally the test is negative because the pressure changes in the EAC cannot be transmitted to the labyrinth.

Positive Fistula Test is seen in:

  • Erosion of horizontal semicircular canal (Cholesteatoma or fenestration operation)
  • Abnormal opening in oval window (post stapedectomy fistula) or round window (rupture of round window).

questions.text:
A 40-yrs-old G3P2 obese woman with Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus presents at 37 weeks gestation. She previously had 2 normal vaginal deliveries of babies of 3.3 and 3.5 kgs. Present estimated weight of the fetus is 3 kgs by USG: Her most recent HbA1c was 6.0. The patient reports that her sugars are within the normal range.
Which of the following is correct about the management of this patient?

choices.text: The patient should undergo an elective cesarean section at 38 weeks to avoid shoulder dystocia
The patient should be induced by 37-38 weeks if spontaneous labor does not occur
After 6 weeks postpartum, the patient should undergo a 75-g glucose tolerance test
In the postpartum period, it is acceptable to use oral contraceptives.

questions.solution:
Elective C.S is not the best option in this case since the weight of the baby and the prenatal investigations are all good and hence a trial of labour is an obvious option. Diabetes in itself is never an indication of a cesarean section.

Moreover, the previous two normal deliveries of baby weights of 3.3 and 3.5 kgs are indicative of an adequate pelvis

A post-partum GTT is not required in an overt diabetic

OCPs are not recommended in post-partum period as such because the estrogen component significantly reduces breast milk production, and more so in diabetics as they effect carbohydrate metabolism adversely

questions.text: A patient of infertility, treated with ovulation induction drugs & Inj HCG for ovulation. After 5 days, she comes to OPD with complaints of abdominal distension with pain, nausea, vomiting. USG reveals subclinical ascites. Which of the following is the next step in management?

choices.text: Outpatient management with limited activity, daily weight record and fluid balance
Hospitalise, input output charting and iv fluid administration
Hospitalise, albumin infusion, input/ output charting

questions.solution:
Patient has history of infertility treatment with clomiphene and HCG and has symptoms after 5 days of hcg, she is a case of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome

Management of OHSS:

Here outpatient management is appropriate, as she has mild OHSS, the patient should be instructed to limit her activity, to weigh herself daily, and to monitor her fluid intake (at least 1 L/day of mostly electrolyte-balanced fluid) and output

Indications for hospitalization include a more severe grade of OHSS with

  • Inability to tolerate oral hydration
  • hemodynamic instability
  • respiratory compromise
  • tense ascites
  • hemoconcentration
  • leukocytosis
  • hyponatremia, hyperkalemia
  • abnormal renal or liver function
  • decreased oxygen saturation

questions.text: You are an intern posted in gynecology OPD. A 38-year-old woman presents for a routine cervical cancer screen. Which of the following is used to take cervical smear?
questions.solution:
Ayre’s spatula

  • Used to take cervical smear (Pap smear)
  • It is a wooden spatula with U-shaped openings on one side and a flat surface on another.
  • Takes sample from the squamocolumnar junction.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female was transferred to your hospital for further evaluation of fever and anterior neck pain that had persisted for more than one month. 4 weeks prior to admission to our hospital, she had had a sore throat and otalgia, symptoms that had improved after medication at private clinics. Two days later, fever and anterior neck pain developed. The patient was treated with antipyretics but her fever persisted. FNAC was done in your hospital which showed follicular destruction and giant cell formation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is subacute thyroiditis

Subacute thyroiditis

  • Can occur in painful or painless forms
  • Painful thyroiditis is thought to be viral in origin or result from a post viral inflammatory response
  • Most commonly occurs in 30- to 40-year-old women
  • Sudden or gradual onset of neck pain radiating to jaw or ear
  • Often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection
  • Gland is enlarged, exquisitely tender and firm
  • 4 phases - initial hyperthyroid x- euthyroid — hypothyroid - resolution and return to euthyroid state
  • ESR is raised
  • FNAC is diagnostic - demonstrates giant cells of an epitheloid foreign body type , which characterise the lesion
  • Microscopic pathology shows large follicles infiltrated by mononuclear cells, neutrophils and lymphocytes
  • Self-limited and treatment is primarily symptomatic

questions.text: All of the given options suit the following statement “Disorders that accompany benign or malignant tumors but are not directly related to mass effects or invasion” except?
questions.solution:
• The statement given describes Paraneoplastic syndrome
  • It comes under metabolic or hormonal related oncological emergencies.
  • Conditions which comes under paraneoplastic syndrome are
    • Hypercalcemia
    • SIADH
    • Cushing syndrome
  • Tumor lysis syndrome is treatment related oncologic emergencies.

questions.text: A term newborn presents with frothing, excessive drooling, and coughing with feeds. Orogastric tube insertion is not successful as the insertion was stopped by some interruption. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In a newborn with frothing, excessive drooling & coughing with feeds, with history of antenatal polyhydramnios suggests a diagnosis ofEsophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (EA with TEF)
  • With the help of interruption of OG tube, it should be either Type A or Type Ctracheoesophageal fistula as there is proximal atresia
  • Classification of TEF:
    • Type A: Atresia only (60%)
    • Type B: Atresia with proximal TEF (2%)
    • Type C:Atresia with distal TEF(85%): most common
    • Type D: Atresia with both proximal and distal TEF (rare)
    • Type E:Isolated TEF (H-type) (1%)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct about the drug Ketamine?

It is a phencyclidine derivative
It is associated with thalamocortical dissociation
It causes parasympathetic stimulation
Post-op delirium caused by the drug is treated with IV benzodiazepines
questions.solution:
Ketamine:

  • Phencyclidine derivative
  • Dissociative anesthesia (aka) Thalamocortical dissociation
  • Patient remains conscious but not oriented in time (or) place
    • Thalamocortical & Limbic dissociation
  • Use: Simple superficial painful procedures can be done under dissociative Anesthesia.
  • Ketamine causes Sympathetic stimulation
  • Mechanism: Stops the metabolism of catecholamines ↓
  • In absence of catecholamines no sympathetic stimulation
  • Side effects:
    • Post-operative delirium & Hallucination
  • Predisposing factors:
    • Patient being given Anticholinergic drugs
    • Adult (less in children)
  • Rx & Prevention: IV Benzodiazepines (Midazolam)

questions.text: 45 years old male came to the hospital with a complaint of fever, associated with abdominal pain. On examination, the patient presents with multiple purpura over the abdomen. Blood examination revealed absolute eosinophilic count > 1000/mm3 and found to be ANCA positive. The patient is a known case of allergic asthma. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Known as eosinophilic granulomatous polyangiitis
  • Small vessel vasculitis with granuloma formation associated with eosinophilic infiltration in the affected vessel
  • It differs from other ANCA positive vasculitis because of eosinophilic infiltration · Some patients have a prodromal period for many years, characterised by allergic rhinitis, nasal polyposis and late-onset asthma that is often difficult to control.
  • The typical acute presentation is with a triad of skin lesions (purpura or nodules), asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia.
  • Pulmonary infiltrates and pleural or pericardial effusions due to serositis may be present.
  • Management is with high-dose glucocorticoids and cyclophosphamide, followed by maintenance therapy with low-dose glucocorticoids and azathioprine, methotrexate
  • Henoch-Schonlein Purpura is ruled out because it usually comes to the children and young adult age group and it is Non-ANCA associated vasculitis.

questions.text: A 25-years-old unmarried gentleman sustained a burn injury to his right upper limb when his hand was trapped in a steam-rolling machine for making carpets under high temperature. On examination, a third-degree circumferential burn in the right arm & forearm region was noted. Which of the following has to be closely monitored in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Circulation to the peripheries should be assessed as compartment syndrome may develop eventually
  • Full thickness burns with a rigid eschar can form a tourniquet effect as the edema progresses, leading to compromised venous outflow and eventually arterial inflow
  • Most common in circumferential extremity burns
  • Warning signs of impending compartment syndrome may include
    • parasthesias
    • pain
    • decreased capillary refill
    • progression to loss of distal pulses

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady came to OPD with the h/o post-menopausal bleeding for 2 months. On vaginal examination, a growth of 1 x 2 cm is found on anterior lip of cervix, normal uterine size. On rectal examination, rectal mucosa and parametrium are free. Punch biopsy of lesion established a diagnosis of Ca cervix. What would be the management?
questions.solution:
The patient has a clinically visible lesion measuring 2 cm without parametrial involvement. This is clinical stage IB2 of cervical cancer

Treatmentof Stage 1B2 is Radical Hysterectomy (Type 3) with Pelvic Lymphadenectomy

Uterus, cervix, upper 1/3-1/2 vagina, entire parametria, uterine artery ligated at its origin from internal iliac artery, uterosacral ligament at most distal attachment (rectum)

Simple extra fascial Hysterectomy (type I) is done only for stage 1A1 tumors without lymphovascular space invasion

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came to your clinic for mental health counseling. In a conversation, the patient gives a statement “The newsreader is keep on talking news about me”. Which of the following is described here?
questions.solution:
• Delusion of reference: False belief that the behavior of others refers to oneself or that events, objects, or other people have a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature; derived from idea of reference, in which persons falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g., belief that people on television or radio are talking to or about the person).
  • Erotomania/ Declerambault syndrome: The patient has the delusional conviction that another person, usually of higher status, is in love with him or her.
  • Delusion of grandeur: The patient had a delusional belief of having special powers
  • Delusion of infidelity: Delusional disorder with delusions of infidelity has been called conjugal paranoia when it is limited to the delusion that a spouse has been unfaithful.

questions.text: A 40 years old American female on her visit to India developed Right lower quadrant pain in the abdomen. The patient was diagnosed with acute appendicitis and planned for laparoscopic appendectomy. In the surgery, the patient suddenly developed signs of acidosis & renal failure associated with myoglobinuria. Which of the following would be not seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient’s signs of acidosis and renal failure associated myoglobinuria moves the diagnosis towards the Malignant hyperthermia.
  • Hypercalcemia is not seen in malignant hyperthermia because there is intracellular increase of calcium not serum calcium
  • Malignant hyperthermia (MH) is one of the most devastating anesthesia-related complications.
  • This fulminant syndrome is elicited by the administration of triggering anesthetic agents, such as a volatile anesthetic or a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent.
  • Signs & Symptoms of malignant hyperthermia due to Hypermetabolism
    • Hypercapnia
    • Hyperthermia
    • Hypertension
    • Tachycardia
    • Arrythmia
  • Signs & symptoms if malignant hyperthermia due to Cell lysis
    • Acidosis
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Myoglobinuria
    • Rhabdomyolysis
    • Renal failure
  • M/C electrolyte abnormality seen in MH is Hyperkalemia
  • M/C cause of death in MH is arrhythmia
  • If patient survives arrhythmia
  • Renal failure is the cause of death
  • Treatment of malignant hyperthermia is done by removing the offending agent and start IV dantrolene infusion

questions.text: You are an intern attending ENT Opd, receiving a 37 yr old male presents with persistent ear pain and discharge, retro-orbital pain. After several investigations, Modified radical mastoidectomy was done to him. Patient comes back again after few days with persistent discharge, what is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the question patient is a case of CSOM, with local spread of infection.
  • Dhingra clearly mentions in a patient with CSOM, persistent ear discharge with or without deep seated pain in spite of an adequate cortical or modified mastoidectomy points towards petrositis.
  • Persistent ear discharge with or without deep seated pain in spite of an adequate cortical or modified radical mastoidectomy also points to petrositis.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about the procedure shown in the image except:

choices.text: Gold standard lithotripter is Dornier unmodified HM-3
Steinstrasse is seen in cases of distal ureteric obstruction
Maximum size of stone removed is 1.5 cm

questions.solution:
ESWL- Extracorporeal Shock wave Lithotripsy

  • Gold standard Lithotripter- Dornier Unmodified HM-3.
  • Shock waves recognizes the stone with help of density changes in body→ erosion and shattering of stones → fragmentation of stones → excreted via ureter.
  • If there is obstruction in ureter, stone fragments are collected in the proximal part of ureter leading to a complication known as Steinstrasse(aka Street of stones/ Columnation of Gravel)
  • Maximum size of stone removed by ESWL is2cm.

Absolute contraindications of ESWL:

  • Pregnancy
  • Bleeding disorders

Relative contraindications of ESWL: → Pacemaker

  • UTI
  • Distal obstruction
  • Obesity
  • Orthopedic abnormalities like Scoliosis and Kyphoscoliosis
  • Uncontrolled HTN
  • Aneurysm
  • Renal failure

Whenever ESWL cannot be used→ PCNL is preferred

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the department of surgery. During a laparoscopic procedure, you notice a similar thing as shown in the image shown below. Identify:
questions.solution:
1.Veress Needle

  • Sharp tipped needle – penetrates the abdominal wall
  • Blunt tipped obturator – Spring forward
  • Intraperitoneal position– Saline Drop test
  • Used to create pneumo peritoneum

questions.text: 24 years old man sustained with road traffic accident arrived at the emergency department with multiple injuries all over the body. On suspecting Upper limb fracture, X-ray were ordered and the X-ray image is depicted below. In relation to the given X-ray image, all of the following signs and symptoms present in this patient except?
questions.solution:
• This is a classic case of elbow fracture
  • Elbow fracture are prone to the injuries of multiple nerves
  • In this case, with the options given, the patient is suspected to have radial nerve injuries
  • In elbow injuries, there is usually low radial nerve palsy

Radial nerve injuries

High Radial nerve palsy Low Radial nerve palsy
  • Wrist drop
  • Sensory loss
  • Finger Drop
  • Brachioradialis paralysis
  • Wrist drop
  • Sensory loss
  • Finger Drop

questions.text: 5 years old triangular-faced child came to the hospital with a systolic murmur. The patient had a history of clay-colored stools and generalized pruritus. Incidental finding of butterfly-shaped vertebra revealed. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alagille syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant disease associated with intrahepatic cholestasis.
  • The patient presents with triangular faces with associated heart diseases
  • The patient usually presents to the hospital with complaints pertinent to cholestasis such as high colored urine, clay colored stools and generalized pruritus due to deposition of bile salts.
  • Deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins is seen.
  • Triangular faces, pointed chin, prominent ears, cardiac murmurs and butterfly vertebrae are seen in Alagille syndrome.

questions.text: 65 years old diabetic female came to the hospital with complaints of recurrent urinary tract infection. She is a known case of congenital heart disease. The patient is on multiple drugs. Which of the following drug is responsible for recurrent urinary tract infection?
questions.solution:
Sodium glucose transporter 2 inhibitors (SGLT2 inhibitors)

  • It is used for treatment of diabetes result in glycosuria and may be associated with small increases in the risk of UTI.
  • Women with diabetes have a two- to threefold higher rate of ASB and UTI than women without diabetes.
  • There is insufficient evidence on which to base a corresponding statement about men.
  • Increased duration of diabetes and the use of insulin rather than oral medication are associated with an elevated risk of UTI among women with diabe­tes.
  • Poor bladder function, obstruction in urinary flow, and incomplete voiding are additional factors commonly found in patients with diabe­tes that increase the risk of UTI.
  • Impaired cytokine secretion may con­tribute to ASB in diabetic women.

questions.text: A newborn baby presents to the NICU with undescended testis associated with deficient abdominal structure and passing urine through umbilicus. The baby has antenatal history of oligohydramnios. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Prune belly syndrome also known as triad syndrome/ Eagle Barrett syndrome
  • 95% of the affected are male
  • The characteristic association of deficient abdominal muscles, undescended testis and urinary tract abnormalities are seen.
  • Oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia are the most common perinatal complications
  • Many affected newborns are stillborn.
  • Urinary tract abnormalities include massive dilatation of ureters, upper tracts, and urinary bladder with a patent urachus or diverticulum.
  • In females, anomalies of the urethra, uterus and vagina are usually present.

questions.text: A 2-year-old born to a consanguineous married couple had a history of the collodian membrane. He had large, thick, plate-like brown scaling generalized distribution; no erythroderma, and ectropion. Which disease is it?
questions.solution:
Lamellar Ichthyosis(LI)

  • Colloidion baby -the baby is covered by a thickened colloidion membrane.
  • Scaling occurs over the whole body including creases and bends.
  • Scale in LI - large, dark brown or grey and firmly adherent.
  • Drooping of lower eyelids(ectropion), palmoplantar keratoderma & scarring alopecia seen insevere cases.
ICHTHYOSIS VULGARIS X LINKED ICHTHYOSIS LAMELLAR ICHTHYOSIS
AD XLR AR
Def. of filaggrin Def. of steroid sulphatase enzyme Def. of transglutaminase-1 enzyme
Fine scalesExtensors mainly involvedWinter exacerbation Thick brown hyperkeratosisFlexors sparedBirth complications Larger thick brown plate like hyperkeratosisWhole body involved ??' Colloidion membrane/ baby

Netherton syndrome:

  • Newborn have skin that is red and scaly (ichthyosiform erythroderma)
  • Triad - congenital icthyosis, hair shaft abnormality, severe atopic diathesis.

questions.text:
Match List I with List II and select the correct answer using the code given below the lists:



List I (Auscultatory findings)
List II (Cardiac condition)


A. Narrow split S2
1. Pulmonary hypertension


B. Continuous/Machinery murmur
2.Atrial septal defect


C. Muffled heart sounds
3. Patent ductus arteriosus


D. Wide fixed split S2
4. Pericardial effusion
questions.solution:
Wide Fixed split S2 ASD The extra blood in RV due to shunting takes extra time to exit and leads to delayed P2
Continuous machinery murmur(Gibson murmur) PDA Aorta to pulmonary artery shunt operates in both phases of respiration leading to continuous murmur
Muffled heart sounds Pericardial effusion Massive accumulation of fluid outside the heart will lead to muffling of heart sounds
Narrow variable split S2 PAH Mean pressure>25mm Hg at rest is defined as PAH. The increased pressure affects the gradient between RV and pulmonary artery and leads to early closure of P2. This leads to narrow split S2.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Asian male presented with enlarging hyperpigmented plaque on his right sole as seen in the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Superficial spreading melanomas Nodular melanomas Lentigo maligna melanoma Acral lentiginous melanoma
Younger patients (median age: 5th decade) Slightly older patients than SSM (median age: 7th decade) Elderly patient (median age 8th decade)
Involve intermittently sun? exposed anatomical sites such as the trunk, back and extremities. Occur at any location Chronically sun? exposed cutaneous sites such as the head and neck region or forearm Acral sites which are the palms, soles and subungual region.
Presents as a flat slowly growing irregular lesion with variegated pigmentation that enlarges in a radial manner unless dermal invasion supervenes; this is usually signified clinically by the presence of a raised area. Present as a rapidly expanding nodule that may show ulceration and haemorrhage. Clinically they may be confused with other cutaneous tumours such as basal cell carcinomas, particularly if they are amelanotic. Presents as a large, variegated pigmented macule with irregular edges , parts of which may become raised if dermal invasion supervenes. Present as slowly growing, variegated pigmented macules
Histologically -intra epidermal - large pleomorphic epithelioid melanocyte showing nested and single cell upward migration (Pagetoid epidermal invasion) Histologically -no epidermal component extending beyond the edges of the dermal component (a “cut off” of three rete ridges is used by some authors) Histologically -lentiginous proliferation of atypical melanocytes in severely sun damaged skin, occasional multinucleate or giant melanocytes, confluent lentiginous growth, nesting and pagetoid epidermal invasion. Histologically -single atypical melanocytes scattered along the junctional epidermal layer, associated lymphocytic infiltrate partly obscuring the dermoepidermal junction can be a useful diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female who was diagnosed to have acute appendicitis was planned for an emergency appendicectomy. The patient is very concerned about the scar post-surgery. The incision that is preferred for appendectomy for a better cosmetic approach in this patient is:-
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice for acute uncomplicated appendicitis - emergency appendicectomy

Incisions in open appendicectomy

  • McArthur - McBurney (oblique muscle splitting) incision or Grid iron incision
    • Widely used
    • Made at right angles between the line joining the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus
  • Rockey Davis (transverse) incision /Lanz incision

Better cosmetic approach

  • conservative midline incision
  • Rutherford Morison incision
  • oblique muscle cutting incision
    • Made 2 cm below the umbilicus cantered on the midclavicular- midinguinal line
    • Used if the appendix is para or retrocaecal and fixed

questions.text: A 56 years old patient presented to the emergency with complaints of breathlessness, chest pain, and drowsiness. He is a k/c/o lung cancer. Examination shows engorged and distended neck veins and low BP, soft S1 and S2. Which of the following is incorrect in this case scenario?
questions.solution:
• Lung cancer can exhibit metastasis to heart→ Pericardial effusion.

CARDIAC TAMPONADE

  • The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade.
  • CAUSES - The most common causes of tamponade areidiopathic pericarditis and pericarditissecondary to neoplastic disease, tuberculosis, or bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic dissection, cardiac operation, trauma, and treatment with anticoagulants

CLINICAL FEATURES

  • The three principal features of tamponade (Beck’s triad) are
    • Hypotension,
    • Soft or absent heart sounds, and
    • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent.
  • The quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 mL when the fluid develops rapidly to as much as >2000 mL in slowly developing effusions when the pericardium has had the opportunity to stretch and adapt to an increasing volume.

CLINICAL SUSPICIAN

  • A high index of suspicion for cardiac tamponade is required because in many instances no obvious cause for pericardial disease is apparent, and this diagnosis should be considered in any patient with otherwise unexplained sudden enlargement of the cardiac silhouette, hypotension, and elevation of jugular venous pressure.

ECG

  • There also may be reductions in amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, QRS, or T waves should raise the suspicion of cardiac tamponade.

Paradoxical Pulse 

  • This important clue to the presence of cardiac tamponade consists of a greater than normal (10 mmHg) inspiratory decline in systolic arterial pressure.
  • When severe it may be detected by palpating weakness or even disappearance of the arterial pulse during inspiration, but usually sphygmomanometric measurement of systolic pressure during slow respiration is required.

Blood Pressure

  • Because both ventricles share a tight incompressible covering, i.e. the pericardial sac, the inspiratory enlargement of the right ventricle causes leftward bulging of the interventricular septum, compresses and reduces left ventricular volume; stroke volume, and arterial systolic pressure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman undergoes fertility-sparing surgery for a unilateral germ cell tumor. Histopathology confirms a dysgerminoma. Which of the following markers may be used for follow-up in case of recurrence?
questions.solution:
Placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) are produced by up to 95% of dysgerminomas, and serial measurements of LDH may be useful for monitoring the disease.

A karyotype should be obtained preoperatively for all premenarcheal girls, particularly those with dysgerminomas, because of the propensity of these tumors to arise in dysgenetic gonads

questions.text: 70 years old female presents to the hospital with complaints of diarrheal episodes - > 3 times in the past 8 hours, watery, yellow stools- not bloodstained. Her blood examination revealed unexplained leukocytosis. On further history, the patient was hospitalized for more than 2 weeks for UTI infection and being treated with antibiotics. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The case described here is Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea
  • Clostridium difficile infection is a unique colonic disease that is acquired most commonly in association with antimicrobial use and the consequent disruption of the normal colonic microbiota
  • Clindamycin, ampicillin, and cephalosporins were the first antibiotics associated with CDI.
  • A clue to the presence of unsus­pected CDI in these patients is unexplained leukocytosis, with ≥15,000 white blood cells (WBCs)/μL
  • C. difficile is acquired exogenously—most often in the hospital or nursing home, but also in the outpatient setting
  • It is carried in the stool of both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients.
  • The rate of fecal colonization increases in proportion to length of hospital stay and is often ≥20% among adult patients hospitalized for >2 weeks; in contrast, the rate is 1–3% among community residents
  • The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:
    • Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause plus
    • Detection of toxin A or B in the stool, detec­tion of toxin-producing C. difficile in the stool by nucleic acid ampli­fication testing (NAAT; e.g., polymerase chain reaction [PCR]) or by culture, or visualization of pseudo membranes in the colon

questions.text: 30 years old female patient with complement deficiency came to the hospital with complaints of migratory arthritis associated with fever and chills. On further history and examination, the patient presents with hemorrhagic pustules which progressed from small papules on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Due to N. gonorrhoeae is a consequence of bacteremia arising from gonococcal infection or, more frequently, from asymptomatic gonococcal mucosal colonization of the urethra, cervix, or pharynx
  • Women are at greatest risk during menses and during pregnancy and overall are two to three times more likely than men to develop disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) and arthritis.
  • Persons with complement deficiencies, especially of the terminal components, are prone to recurrent episodes of gonococcemia.
  • Most common manifestation of DGI is a syndrome of fever, chills, rash, and articular symptoms.
  • Small numbers of papules that progress to hemorrhagic pustules develop on the trunk and the extensor surfaces of the distal extremities.
  • Migratory arthritis and tenosynovitis of the knees, hands, wrists, feet, and ankles are prominent.

questions.text: Lalit, a 19 years old male presented to cardiac OPD with complaints of dyspnea and chest pain following exercise. His elder brother had same symptoms and he died 2 years ago by sudden collapse while participating in a marathon event. O/E - Jerky pulse and double apical impulse on palpation, Narrow split S2 and Crescendo decrescendo murmur is heard on auscultation. Genetic analysis showed the disease to be A/w multiple genes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Familial HCM, AD Mendelian inherited disease in approximately 50% of cases.
  • Greater than 100 mutations have been identified in at least 12 sarcomeric genes withβ-myosin heavy chainbeing most frequently affected, followed bymyosin-binding protein Candtroponin T.
  • These three genes account for 70% to 80% of all cases of HCM.
  • In Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia the ventricular wall is severely thinned as a result of myocyte replacement by massive fatty infiltration and lesser amounts of fibrosis.
  • Genetic association-
    • HOCM= mutation of beta-myosin heavy chain
    • MVP= deficiency of Type 3 collagen
    • DCM= mc = Autosomal Dominant=Protein Titin defect
    • AR = Desmosome= Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia & desmopressin defect
    • XR= only males = Tafazzin

questions.text: A patient presents with hyperacusis, loss of lacrimation and loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. Oedema extends up to which level of facial nerve:

choices.text: Vertical part beyond nerve to stapedius
Vertical part and beyond nerve to stapedius

questions.solution:
In the question patient is presenting with

  1. hyperacusis which means nerve to stapedius is involved which arises from the vertical / descending part of facial nerve.
  2. loss of lacrimation – i.e. greater superficial petrosal Nerve which arises from geniculate ganglion is involved.
  3. Loss of taste sensation in anterior 2/3 of tongue –i.e. chorda tympani nerve which arises from vertical/descending part of facial nerve is involved
  • Any lesion will lead to paralysis of all Nerves distal to it and will spare proximal nerves
  • Hence – we will have to look for the most proximal lesion which in this case is geniculate ganglion
  • So lesion is either at or proximal to geniculate ganglion

questions.text: A 40 years old male COVID-19 patient came to the hospital with SpO2 -80%. Your senior doctor asked you to admit the patient in ICU setting and start positive end expiratory pressure. Which of the following is the advantage of PEEP?
questions.solution:

  • Disadvantages of PEEP are

    • Perfusion of Organs would decrease

    • Increased ventricular compliance

questions.text: 60 years old male diabetic patient came to the hospital with reports confirming bladder cancer. The patient is on oral hypoglycaemic agents for the past 20 years. Which of the following drugs might be responsible for bladder cancer?
questions.solution:
Thiazolidinediones

  • Thiazolidinediones have been prescribed widely since the late 1990s but a number of adverse effects have become apparent and their use has declined.
  • One popular TZD, rosiglitazone, was reported to increase the risk of myocardial infarction and was withdrawn in 2010.
  • The other TZD in common use, pioglitazone, does not appear to increase the risk of myocardial infarction but may exacerbate cardiac failure by causing fluid retention, and recent data show that it increases the risk of bone fracture and possibly bladder cancer.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient came to your clinic for mental health counseling. In a conversation, the patient gives a statement "I have choose right over wrong. When there are two options, I have to look to the right. I can choose left or right, but always look right." Which of the following is described here?
questions.solution:
• Derailment - (Synonymous with loose associations) - A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal directedness.
  • The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
  • Typically a feature of schizophrenia, and some other mental disorders including obsessive–compulsive disorder, and mania
  • Thought blocking - A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas
  • Circumstantiality. Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point.
  • Tangentiality. In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question.

questions.text: All of the following are true about abdominal compartment syndrome except:

choices.text: Characterized by an increased peak inspiratory pressure, decreased urinary output
Can lead to fatal complications due to pulmonary failure and mesenteric vascular compromise
A urinary bladder catheter is the gold standard indirect method used to measure IAP
Grade III abdominal compartment syndrome is managed by hypovolemic resuscitation

questions.solution:
Solutions: - ABDOMINAL COMPARTMENT SYNDOME

  • ACS is defined as increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP > 20mm Hg) resulting in compression of abdominal structures, producing fatal complications due to pulmonary failure and mesenteric vascular compromise.
  • Normal IAP = 5-7 mm Hg: intra-abdominal hypertension IAP ≥ 12 mm Hg
  • ACS occurs predominantly in:
    • Patients in profound shock:
    • Patients requiring large amounts of resuscitation fluids & blood
    • Those with major visceral or vascular abdominal injuries
  • IVC compressed →Decreased Venous return→ Decrease Cardiac Output → Decrease systolic blood pressure → Decrease renal blood flow & vascular blood flow → decrease GFR → decrease urine output.
Physiologic consequences of increased intra-abdominal Pressure
Decreased Increased
  • Cardiac output
  • Central venous return
  • Visceral blood flow
  • Renal blood flow
  • Glomerular filtration
  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

Abdominal Compartment syndrome grading system
Grade Bladder pressure (mm Hg) Clinical features Treatment
I 12-15 None Normovolemic resuscitation
II 16-20 Oliguria, splanchnic hypoperfusion Hypovolemic resuscitation
III 21-25 Anuria, increased ventilation pressure Decompression
IV > 25 Anuria, increased ventilation pressure & decreased PO2 Emergency re-exploration

questions.text: 60 years old man came to the hospital with complaints of tenderness over the wrist joint. The patient gives a history of fall with outstretched hand. CT wrist depicts the below image. Which of the following nerve root is most likely to be involved?
