questions.text: A 25-years-old male presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On examination, there is a pelvic fracture and blood at the urethral meatus. All of the following are true about the patient except:

choices.text: Anterior urethra is the most likely site of injury
Retrograde urethrography should be done after the patient is stabilized
Foley catheter can be carefully passed if the retrograde urethrography is normal
Rectal examination may reveal a large perineal hematoma

questions.solution:
The urethra is not a common source of urologic trauma and injury due to external violence accounts for approximately 4% of all genitourinary injuries.

Broadly the urethra is divided into the anterior and posterior segments

  • The anterior segment of the urethra most commonly injured is the bulbarurethra whichaccounts for 85% of urethral injuries. The male anterior urethra may be injured at the time of penile injury
  • Approximately 3% to 6% of posterior urethral injuries are associated with pelvic fracture, the so-called pelvic fracture urethral injury

The classic triad is:

  • Blood at the urethral meatus
  • Inability to void urine
  • Palpably distended bladder

Perineal or butterfly hematoma occurs due to the rupture of Buck fascia. On digital rectal examination, a high riding prostate may be noted

In patients with suspected urethral injury, retrograde urethrography should be performed before the insertion of a Foley catheter. Extravasation of contrast material occurs when continuity of the urethra has been lost because of the injury

Posterior urethral injuries should be managed with suprapubic catheter insertion rather than by instrumentation of the traumatized urethra with risk of further injury.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male came to the OPD with complaints of rectal bleeding occasionally. Rectal examination revealed no haemorrhoidal mass or growth. Colonoscopic examination of the patient revealed multiple polyps in the colon. On further probing history, the patient revealed that his grandfather died of colon carcinoma. The patient was diagnosed to have Familial adenomatous polyps. Which of the following is associated with FAP?
questions.solution:
Variants of FAP

1. Gardner’s syndrome

→ Autosomal dominantcondition

→ Associated with

  • Osteoma (MC bone involved→Mandible)
  • Congenital hypertrophied retinal pigmented epithelium
  • Desmoid tumors
  • Sebaceous cyst
  • Benign lymphoid polyposis of ileum
  • Supernumerary teeth (extra teeth)

2. Turcot’s syndrome

→ Autosomal recessive condition

→ Associated with Brain tumors

Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)

→Autosomal dominant

→ Characterized by APC gene (Adenomatous Polyposis Coli) mutation

→ Located on Chromosome 5q 21 (long-arm)

→ Characterized by > 100 adenomatous polyps

→ Associated with 100% risk of malignancy

→ Flexible sigmoidoscopy of first degree relatives starting at age 10 to 15 years has been the traditional mainstay of screening

→ IOC for screening of family members of FAP patients- APC Gene testing

→ Treatment

Restorative proctocolectomy + Ileal pouch anal anastomosis (J shaped pouch created)

Total proctocolectomy with an end (Brooke) ileostomy

Total abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis

questions.text: You are presenting a case about middle ear pathology. You are very uncertain about the tuning fork tests. Your ENT professor questioned you, "In the right middle ear pathology, Weber’s test will be"?
questions.solution:
• In normal Individuals – No lateralization of sound occurs as Bone conduction of both ears in normal and equal.
  • In conductive deafness (seen in External ear and Middle ear disorders) – Lateralization of sound occurs to the diseased ear
  • In SNHL (seen in Inner ear and Neural pathway disorders) – Lateralization of sound occurs to the better ear.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy came to ophthalmologist for correction of his eyesight. After evaluation of his eyesight the doctor found that one of his eyes was myopic and other was hypermetropic .The doctor advised immediate correction of the defects either surgically or non surgically. Which of the following is the most Preferred Non-surgical Management of Anisometropia ?
questions.solution:
The optical state with equal refraction in the two eyes is termed isometropia. When the total refraction of the two eyes is unequal the condition is called anisometropia. Anisometropia can lead to amblyopia hence management is very important

TREATMENT-

  • Spectacles correction can take care of anisometropia up to 4D (some patients may not tolerate as high)
  • Contact lenses - for higher degrees of anisometropia.
  • Intraocular lens–implantation for uniocular aphakia.
  • Refractive corneal Surgery
  • Phakic Refractive Lenses (PRL) and Refractive Lens Exchange (RLE)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with small amounts of urinary leakage in the past 1 year. Her incontinence occurs only during coughing or sneezing. She has been advised of some pelvic floor exercises, but she was not relieved. Which of the following surgeries may be useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Stress incontinence – involuntary escape of urine with the increase of abdominal pressure.

Treatment of stress incontinence
Conservative Surgical

1) Pelvic floor muscle training

2) Bio feedback therapy

3) Drugs

4) Paraurethral implants

1) Kelly's plication

2) Bursch colposuspension

3) MMK procedure

4) Transvaginal sling

5) Trans obturator sling

6) Laparoscopic suspension of bladder neck

Types stress incontinence according to the cause

  • Type I: Incontinence due to loss of posterior urethrovesical angle alone.
  • Type II: Incontinence due loss of posterior urethrovesical angle as well as urethral hypermobility
  • Type III: Incontinence due to intrinsic sphincter deficiency (ISD)

Other options

  • Le Fort: surgery for vaginal proplapse for older women unfit for a vaginal hysterectomy
  • Manchester: uterine conservative surgery for prolapse
  • Posterior colporhaphy: done along with vaginal hysterectomy for posterior compartment tightening

questions.text: Tendon used for repair of flexor tendon injury in hand requiring reconstruction from forearm to fingertip is:
questions.solution:
• Tendons used for reconstruction
    • Palmaris longus—Hand to fingertip
    • Plantaris—Forearm to fingertip (plantaris is longest tendon in the body)
  • Tendons are used for reconstruction in case of delayed repair when primary repair is not possible e.g. in case of wound contamination or lack of skin coverage or unusual delay in primary repair
  • Prerequisites are that there should be full passive range of joint movement preoperatively.
  • In case the pulleys are intact and there are no adhesions then the graft from palmaris longus or plantaris is used for reconstruction in a single sitting.
  • In case pulleys are not intact, then the tendons are excised and the pulleys are reconstructed using the excised tendons and A Silastic rod is sutured to the distal stump of the profundus tendon and left free proximally in either the palm or distal forearm.
  • Rehabilitation is planned to maintain a good range of movement. A smooth gliding surface forms around the rod.
  • After 3 months palmaris longus or plantaris tendons are used for reconstruction of tendons by suturing the proximal and distal ends of the flexor tendons after removing the rods.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient who was working in the glass manufacturing industry presented to the burn unit with a Hydrofluoric acid burn caused by the explosion of a 5-liter acid container. On physical examination, second and third-degree burns involving 5% of his TBSA were noted (image). The lesions induced by the HF burn on the left forearm and the trunk were immediately cleaned with plenty of water, then his clothes were removed. The common electrolyte abnormality that can be expected in this patient would be:
questions.solution:
• Hydrofluoric acid causes Hypocalcemia
  • Calcium based therapies are main stay of treating Hydrofluoric acid burns
  • Topical application of calcium gluconate onto wounds and IV administration of calcium gluconate for systemic symptoms
  • Intra-arterial calcium gluconate infusion provides effective treatment of progressive tissue injury and intense pain

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with chest pain, which mimics angina and dysphagia. The barium swallow finding is given below. Which of the following statement is not correct about this condition?

choices.text: Caused by secondary contraction of esophagus
Symptoms are pronounced during times of heightened emotional stress
Gold standard for diagnosis is Manometry
Mainstay of treatment is nonsurgical by nitrates/calcium channel blockers or endoscopic intervention (Bougie dilation)

questions.solution:
40 years old, male Chest pain Dysphagia Barium Swallow shows- Cork screw appearance- Rosary bead appearance- Pseudo-diverticulum appearance Diffuse Esophageal spasm (DES)

It is due to tertiary contractions of esophagus

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm/ Distal esophageal spasm

  • Esophageal contractions are repetitive, simultaneous, and of high amplitude
  • Basic pathology is related to a motor abnormality of the esophageal body that is most notable in the lower two thirds of the esophagus.
  • More common in women and is often found in patients with multiple complaints

Clinical feature

  • Clinical presentation: Chest pain and dysphagia (may be related to eating or exertion and may mimic angina)
  • Complaints of squeezing pressure in the chest that may radiate to the jaw, arms, and upper back
  • The symptoms are often pronounced during times of heightened emotional stress
  • Regurgitation of esophageal contents and saliva is common but acid reflux is not

Diagnosis

  • Barium swallow:
    • Corkscrew or rosary-bead esophagus, segmental spasm or pseudo diverticulosis appearance
    • Due to presence of tertiary contractions
    • Indicative of advanced disease

Manometry is gold standard test for diagnosis

  • Simultaneous multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds)

Treatment:

  • Mainstay of treatment for DES is nonsurgical, and pharmacologic (Nitrates, calcium channel blockers) or endoscopic intervention (Bougie dilation) is preferred

Indications of surgery (long esophagomyotomy):

  • Incapacitating chest pain or dysphagia who have failed medical and endoscopic therapy
  • Presence of pulsion diverticulum of the thoracic esophagus
